15.21: The rest of Menahem's activities, including everything that he did, are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel, are they not?
15.22: Then Menahem died, as did his ancestors, and his son Pekahiah reigned in his place.
15.23: Menahem's son Pekahiah became king over Israel for two years during the fiftieth year of the reign of King Azariah of Judah.
15.24: He did what the LORD considered to be evil. Just as Nebat's son Jeroboam had led Israel into sin, so also Pekahiah did not stop doing the same thing.
15.25: Then Remaliah's son Pekah, Pekahiah's officer, conspired against him with Argob and Arieh. Accompanied by 50 Gileadite men, Pekah attacked Pekahiah inside the palace of the king's compound in Samaria, executed him, and reigned as king in his place.
15.26: The rest of Pekahiah's activities, including everything he did, are written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel.
15.27: Remaliah's son Pekah began a 20-year reign as Israel's king during the fifty-second year of King Azariah of Judah.
15.28: He did what the LORD considered to be evil by never abandoning the sins of Nebat's son Jeroboam, by which he caused Israel to sin.
15.29: During the lifetime of King Pekah of Israel, King Tiglath-pileser of Assyria attacked. He captured the cities of Ijon, Abel Beth Maacah, Janoah, Kedesh, and Hazor. He also captured Gilead, Galilee, and the entire territory of Naphtali, and carried its people off to Assyria.
15.30: So during the twentieth year of the reign of Uzziah's son Jotham, Elah's son Hoshea conspired against Remaliah's son Pekah, attacked him, executed him, and became king in his place.
15.31: The rest of Pekah's activities, including everything that he accomplished, are written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel.
15.32: Uzziah's son Jotham became king over Judah during the second year of the reign of Remaliah's son Pekah, king of Israel.
15.33: He was 25 years old when he became king. He reigned sixteen years in Jerusalem. Zadok's daughter Jerusha was his mother.
15.34: He did what the LORD considered to be right, following everything his father Uzziah had done,
15.35: except the high places were not torn down, and the people still sacrificed and burned incense on the high places. But he rebuilt the upper gate of the LORD's Temple.
15.36: The rest of Jotham's activities, including everything that he accomplished, are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah, are they not?
15.37: Right about that time, the LORD began to send King Rezin of Aram and Remaliah's son Pekah against Judah.
15.38: Meanwhile, Jotham died, as did his ancestors, and was buried with them in the City of David, his ancestor. Then Jotham's son Ahaz reigned in his place.

16.1: During the seventeenth year of the reign of Remaliah's son Pekah, Jotham's son Ahaz became king of Judah.
16.2: Ahaz was 20 years old when he became king, and he ruled in Jerusalem for sixteen years. He did not practice what the LORD considered to be right, as had his ancestor David.
16.3: Instead, he behaved like the kings of Israel did by making his son pass through fire, the very same abomination that the heathen practiced, whom the LORD evicted from the land right in front of the Israelis.
16.4: Furthermore, Ahaz sacrificed and burned incense on the high places, on top of hills, and under every green tree.
16.5: Later, King Rezin of Aram and Remaliah's son Pekah, king of Israel, approached Jerusalem to attack it. They besieged Ahaz but could not conquer him.
16.6: But at that time, King Rezin of Aram recovered Elath for Aram, completely removing the Judeans from Elath. Then the Arameans returned to Elath and have remained there to this day.
16.7: So Ahaz sent envoys to Tiglath-pileser, king of Assyria, to tell him, "I am your servant and son. Save me from the king of Aram and the king of Israel, who are attacking me."
16.8: Then Ahaz took the silver and gold that was in the LORD's Temple and in the palace treasuries and sent them as a gift to the king of Assyria,
16.9: so the king of Assyria listened to Ahaz. He attacked Damascus, captured it, sent its people away into exile to Kir, and executed Rezin.
16.10: King Ahaz traveled to Damascus and met with King Tiglath-pileser of Assyria, where he observed the altar at Damascus. So King Ahaz sent a set of construction patterns of this altar to Uriah the priest.
16.11: Uriah the priest built an altar, following the plans that King Ahaz had sent him from Damascus and finishing the altar before King Ahaz returned from Damascus.
16.12: When the king returned from Damascus, as soon as he saw the altar, he approached it and offered sacrifices on it.
16.13: He presented a burnt offering, a meat offering, poured out a drink offering, and sprinkled the blood of a peace offering on his altar.
16.14: Then he took the bronze altar that stood in the LORD's presence from in front of the Temple, moved it to the north side of his altar,
16.15: and issued these orders to Uriah the priest: "Burn the morning burnt offering, the evening grain offering, the king's burnt offering and grain offering, the whole burnt offering, the grain offering, and the drink offering on behalf of all the people of the land on the large altar. And sprinkle all the blood from the burnt offering and from the sacrifice. But I will use the bronze altar to ask God questions."
16.16: So Uriah the priest did precisely what King Ahaz ordered.
16.17: Later, King Ahaz ordered the side panels removed from the bases, along with the washing bowls that had stood on top of the bases. He also removed the large bowl that was called the Sea from on top of the bronze bulls that supported it, and put it on a stone base.
16.18: Then Ahaz removed the covered walkway for use on the Sabbath that they had built in the Temple. Because of the king of Assyria, he also removed the outside entrance from the LORD's Temple that had been built exclusively for the king.
16.19: Now the rest of Ahaz's activities are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah, are they not?
16.20: Later, Ahaz died, as did his ancestors, and was buried alongside his ancestors in the City of David. His son Hezekiah reigned in his place.

17.1: During the twelfth year of the reign of King Ahaz of Judah, Elah's son Hoshea became king over Israel for nine years in Samaria.
17.2: He practiced what the LORD considered to be evil, though not like the kings of Israel who had preceded him.
17.3: King Shalmaneser of Assyria attacked him, and Hoshea became his servant and paid tribute to him.
17.4: But the king of Assyria uncovered a conspiracy involving Hoshea, who had sent envoys to King So of Egypt and stopped offering tribute to the king of Assyria, as he had done annually. As a result, the king of Assyria placed him under arrest and sent him to prison.
17.5: After this, the king of Assyria invaded the entire land, approached Samaria, and began a three year siege.
17.6: As a result, during the ninth year of the reign of Hoshea, the king of Assyria captured Samaria and took the Israelis off to Assyria, placing them in Halah, along the Habor River in Gozan, and in cities ruled by the Medes.
17.7: This happened because the Israelis had sinned against the LORD their God, who had brought them up from the land of Egypt and from the domination of Pharaoh, king of Egypt, because they were fearing other gods,
17.8: and because they were following the rules of the nations whom the LORD had expelled before the Israelis and that the kings of Israel had practiced.
17.9: The Israelis practiced secret things that were not right, offending the LORD their God. In addition, they built high places for use by all their towns, watchtowers, and fortified cities.
17.10: They set up pillars and Asherim on every high hill and in the shade of every green tree,
17.11: where they made offerings on all the high places, as did the nations whom the LORD had expelled before them. They also practiced other wickedness, provoking the LORD to become angry,
17.12: and they served idols, a practice that the LORD had warned them, "You are not to do this."
17.13: Nevertheless, the LORD had warned both Israel and Judah by means of every prophet and seer: "Turn away from your evil practices and keep my commandments and statutes according to the entire Law that I gave your ancestors and that I sent to you through my servants, the prophets."
17.14: But they would not listen. Instead, they were stubborn, just like their ancestors had been, who did not believe in the LORD their God.
17.15: They rejected the LORD's statutes, the covenant that he had made with their ancestors, and his warnings that he gave them. They pursued meaninglessness—and became meaningless themselves—as they followed the lifestyles of the nations that surrounded them, a practice that the LORD had warned them not to do.
17.16: They abandoned all of the commands given by the LORD their God, crafted for themselves cast images of two calves, constructed an Asherah, worshipped all of the stars in heaven, and served Baal.
17.17: They passed their sons and daughters through fire, practiced divination, cast spells, and sold themselves to practice what the LORD considered to be evil, thereby provoking him.
17.18: As a result, the LORD was angry with Israel and removed them from his presence. No one was left except for the tribe of Judah.
17.19: But Judah, too, did not keep the commands of the LORD their God. Instead, they lived the lifestyle that Israel had chosen,
17.20: so the LORD rejected all of the descendants of Israel, afflicted them, and handed them over to the control of plunderers until he had thrown them away from his presence.
17.21: He ripped them away from the heritage of David, even as the people appointed Nebat's son Jeroboam to be king. Jeroboam drove Israel away from following the LORD and made them commit great sin.
17.22: The Israelis practiced all the sins that Jeroboam had practiced, and never wavered from them
17.23: until the LORD removed Israel from his presence, just as he had warned through all of his prophets who served him. So Israel was carried off into exile from their own land into Assyria, where they remain to this day.
17.24: Because the king of Assyria brought captives from Babylon, Cuthah, Avva, Hamath, and Sephar-vaim and settled them in the cities of Samaria to replace the Israelis, the settlers possessed Samaria and lived in its cities.
17.25: When they first began to live there, the settlers did not fear the LORD, so he sent lions among them, and they killed a few of them.
17.26: As a result, they reported to the king of Assyria, "Because the nations whom you exiled to live in the cities of Samaria don't know the law of the god of the land, he has sent lions among them. Look how the lions are killing them, because they don't know the law of the god of the land!"
17.27: So the king of Assyria issued this order: "Take one of the priests whom you carried away and let him go back and live there. Let him teach them the law of the god of the land."
17.28: So one of the priests whom they had carried away from Samaria went to live in Bethel to teach them how they ought to fear the LORD.
17.29: Nevertheless, each nation continued to craft their own gods and install them in the temples on the high places that the people of Samaria had constructed—every nation in their own cities where they continued to live.
17.30: Settlers from Babylon built Succoth-benoth, settlers from Cuth built Nergal, settlers from Hamath built Ashima,
17.31: and settlers from Avva built Nibhaz and Tartak. The residents of Sephar-vaim burned their children in fire to Adrammelech and Anammelech, the gods of Sephar-vaim.
17.32: Because they feared the LORD, they also appointed from among themselves priests for the high places who acted on their behalf in the temples on the high places.
17.33: While they continued to fear the LORD, they served their own gods, following the custom of the nations whom they had carried away from there.
17.34: To this very day, they still follow the former customs: they don't fear the LORD and they don't live in accordance with the statutes, ordinances, laws, or commandments that the LORD had given to the descendants of Jacob—whom he renamed Israel—
17.35: and with whom the LORD had made a covenant when he gave these orders to them: "You are not to fear other gods, bow down to them, serve them, or sacrifice to them.
17.36: Instead, it is to be the LORD, who brought you up from the land of Egypt, showing great power and public demonstrations of might, whom you are to fear, worship, and to whom you are to offer sacrifice.
17.37: Furthermore, you are to be careful to observe forever the statutes, ordinances, law, and the commandment that he wrote for you. And you are not to fear other gods.
17.38: You are not to forget the covenant that I've made with you, and you are not to fear other gods.
17.39: But you are to fear the LORD, and he will deliver you from the control of all your enemies."
17.40: But they wouldn't listen. Instead, they did what they had been doing before.
17.41: These nations feared the LORD and also served their carved images. Their descendants did the same thing, as did their grandchildren. Just as their ancestors had done, they also do the same thing to this day.

18.1: Now it happened that during the third year of the reign of Elah's son Hoshea, king of Israel, that Ahaz' son Hezekiah became king.
18.2: He was 25 years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for 29 years. His mother was Zechariah's daughter Abi.
18.3: He did what the LORD considered to be right, according to everything that his ancestor David had done.
18.4: He removed the high places, demolished the sacred pillars, and tore down the Asherah poles. He also demolished the bronze serpent that Moses had crafted, because the Israelis had been burning incense to it right up until that time. Hezekiah called it a piece of brass.
18.5: He trusted the LORD God of Israel, and after him there were none like him among all the kings of Judah,
18.6: because he depended on the LORD, not abandoning pursuit of him, and keeping the LORD's commands that he had commanded Moses.
18.7: So the LORD was with him, and Hezekiah prospered wherever he went, even when he rebelled against the king of Assyria, refusing to serve him.
18.8: He attacked the Philistines, invading Gaza and its borders from watchtower to fortified garrison.
18.9: In the fourth year of King Hezekiah's reign (that is, during the seventh year of Elah's son Hoshea's reign as king of Israel), King Shalmaneser from Assyria invaded Samaria and besieged it.
18.10: Three years later, they captured Samaria during the sixth year of Hezekiah's reign, which was the ninth year of Hoshea's reign as king of Israel.
18.11: After this, the king of Assyria carried Israel off into exile in Assyria, settling them in Halah, on the Habor River in Gozan, and in cities controlled by the Medes,
18.12: because they would not obey the voice of the LORD their God. Instead, they transgressed his covenant, including everything that Moses, the servant of the LORD, had commanded, by neither listening nor putting what he had commanded into practice.
18.13: During the fourteenth year of the reign of King Hezekiah, King Sennacherib of Assyria approached all of the walled cities of Judah and seized them.
18.14: So Hezekiah sent this message to the king of Assyria at Lachish: "I have offended you. Withdraw from me, and I'll accept whatever tribute you impose." So the king of Assyria required Hezekiah to pay him 300 talents of silver and 30 talents of gold.
18.15: Hezekiah gave him all the silver that could be removed from the LORD's Temple and from the treasuries in the king's palace.
18.16: At that time, Hezekiah removed the doors to the LORD's Temple and the doorposts that he had overlaid with gold, and gave the gold to the king of Assyria.
18.17: Sometime later, the king of Assyria sent Tartan, Rab-saris, and Rab-shakeh from Lachish to King Hezekiah in Jerusalem, accompanied with a large army.
18.18: When they called for the king, Hilkiah's son Eliakim, who managed the household, Shebnah the scribe, and Asaph's son Joah the recorder went out to them.
18.19: Rab-shakeh told them, "Tell Hezekiah right now, 'This is what the great king, the king of Assyria says: '"Why are you so confident?
18.20: You're saying—but they're only empty words—'I have enough advice and resources to conduct warfare!' '"Now who are you relying on, that you have rebelled against me?
18.21: Look, you're trusting on Egypt to lean on like a staff, but it's a crushed reed, and if you lean on it, it will collapse and pierce your hand. Pharaoh, king of Egypt, is just like that to everyone who relies on him!
18.22: "Of course, you might tell me, "We rely on the LORD our God!" But isn't it he whose high places and whose altars Hezekiah has demolished, all the while telling Jerusalem, "You're to worship in front of this altar in Jerusalem?"'
18.23: "Come now, and make a deal with my master, the king of Assyria, and I'll give you 2,000 horses, if you can furnish them with riders.
18.24: How can you refuse even one official from the least of my master's servants and rely on Egypt for chariots and horsemen?
18.25: "Now then, haven't I come up—apart from the LORD—to attack and destroy this place? The LORD told me, 'Go up against this land and destroy it!'"'"
18.26: At this, Hilkiah's son Eliakim, Shebnah, and Joah asked Rab-shakeh, "Please speak to your servants in Aramaic, because we understand it, but don't speak the language of Judah to us within the hearing of the people who are on the wall."
18.27: But Rab-shakeh spoke to them, "Has my master sent me to talk about this just to your master and to you, and not also to the men who are sitting on the wall, who will soon be eating their own feces and drinking their own urine —along with you?"
18.28: Then Rab-shakeh stood up and cried out loud, "Listen to what the great king, the king of Assyria has to say.
18.29: This is what the king says: 'Don't let Hezekiah deceive you, because he will prove to be unable to deliver you from my control.
18.30: And don't let Hezekiah make you trust in the LORD by telling you, "The LORD will certainly deliver us and this city will not be handed over to the king of Assyria."
18.31: Don't listen to Hezekiah, because this is what the king of Assyria says: "Make peace with me and come out to me! Each of you will eat from his own vine. Each will eat from his own fig tree. And each of you will drink water from his own cistern
18.32: until I come and take you away to a land like your own land, one overflowing with grain and new wine, a land filled with bread and vineyards, with olive trees and honey, so you may live and not die." 'But don't listen to Hezekiah when he misleads you by saying, "The LORD will deliver us!"
18.33: Has any of the gods of the nations delivered his land from control by the king of Assyria?
18.34: Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sephar-vaim, of Hena, and Ivvah? Have they delivered Samaria from my control?
18.35: Who among all the gods of these lands has delivered their land from my control , so that the LORD should deliver Jerusalem from me?'"
18.36: But the people remained silent and did not answer with even so much as a word, because the king's order was, "Don't answer him."
18.37: But Hilkiah's son Eliakim, who managed the household, Shebna the scribe, and Asaph's son Joah the recorder came back to Hezekiah with their clothes torn and told him what Rab-shakeh had said.

19.1: When King Hezekiah heard Eliakim's report, he tore his clothes, put on a sackcloth covering, entered the LORD's Temple,
19.2: and sent Eliakim the household supervisor, Shebna the scribe, and the elders of the priests—all of them covered in sackcloth—to Amoz's son, the prophet Isaiah.
19.3: They announced to him: "This is what Hezekiah says: 'Today is a day of trouble, rebuke, and blasphemy, because children are about to be born, but there is no strength to bring them to birth.
19.4: Perhaps the LORD your God will take note of everything that Rab-shakeh has said, whom his master the king of Assyria sent to taunt the living God, and then he will rebuke the words that the LORD your God has heard. Therefore offer a prayer for the survivors who remain.'"
19.5: That is how the King Hezekiah's servants approached Isaiah.
19.6: In reply, Isaiah responded to them, "Here's how you're to report to your master: 'This is what the LORD says: "Never be afraid of the words that you have heard by which the servants of the king of Assyria have blasphemed me.
19.7: Look! I'm going to cause an attitude to grow within him so that he'll hear a rumor and return to his own territory, where I'll make him die by the sword in his own land!"'"
19.8: So Rab-shakeh returned and found the king of Assyria at war with Libnah, because Rab-shakeh had heard that the king had left Lachish.
19.9: When he heard that it was being said about King Tirhakah of Ethiopia, "Look! He has come out to attack you!" he again sent messengers to Hezekiah. The messengers were told,
19.10: "This is what you are to say to King Hezekiah of Judah: 'Don't let your God in whom you trust deceive you by telling you "Jerusalem won't be turned over to the control of Assyria's king."
19.11: Look! you've heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all the lands—they completely destroyed them! Will you be spared?
19.12: Did the gods of those nations whom my ancestors destroyed deliver them, including Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and Eden's descendants in Telassar?
19.13: Where is the king of Hamath, the king of Arpad, the king of the city of Sephar-vaim, the king of Hena, or the king of Ivvah?'"
19.14: Hezekiah took the messages from the couriers, read them, went up to the LORD's Temple, and laid them out in the presence of the LORD.
19.15: Then Hezekiah prayed in the presence of the LORD, "LORD God of Israel! You live between the cherubim! You alone are the God of all the kingdoms of the earth. You have fashioned the heavens and the earth.
19.16: Turn your ear, LORD, and listen! Open your eyes, LORD, and observe! Listen to the message sent by Sennacherib to insult the living God!
19.17: Truly, LORD, the kings of Assyria have devastated nations and their territories,
19.18: throwing their gods into the fire, since they weren't gods but rather were the product of men's handiwork—wood and stone. And so they destroyed them.
19.19: Now, LORD our God, I'm praying that you will deliver us from his control, so that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that you alone, LORD, are God!"
19.20: Then Amoz's son Isaiah sent word to Hezekiah, "This is what the LORD, the God of Israel says: 'Because you have prayed to me about King Sennacherib of Assyria, I have listened.'"
19.21: "This is what the LORD has spoken against him: 'She despises and mocks you, this virgin daughter of Zion! Behind your back she shakes her head, this daughter of Jerusalem!
19.22: Who are you reproaching and blaspheming? Against whom have you raised your voice? And against whom have you lifted up your eyes in arrogance? Against the Holy One of Israel!
19.23: By your messengers you have insulted the LORD. You have claimed, "With my many chariots I ascended the heights of the mountains, including the remotest regions of Lebanon; I cut down its tall cedars and the best of its cypress trees. I entered its most remote lodging place and its most fruitful forest.
19.24: I myself dug for and drank foreign water. With the sole of my foot I dried up all the streams of Egypt!"
19.25: Didn't you hear? I determined it years ago! I planned this from ancient times, and now I've brought it to pass, to turn fortified cities into piles of ruins
19.26: while their inhabitants, lacking strength, stand dismayed and confused. They were like vegetation out in the fields, and like green herbs— just as grass that grows on a housetop dries out before it can grow.
19.27: But when you sit down, when you go out, and when you come in, I'm aware of it!
19.28: Because of your rage against me, your complacency has reached my ears. I'll put my hook into your nostrils and my bit into your mouth. Then I'll turn you back on the road by which you came.'
19.29: "This will serve as a sign for you: you'll eat this year from what grows by itself, in the second year what grows from that, and in the third year you'll sow, reap, plant vineyards, and enjoy their fruit.
19.30: Those who survive from Judah's household will again put down deep roots and bear fruit extensively,
19.31: because a remnant will go out from Jerusalem, and survivors from Mount Zion. The zeal of the LORD will bring this about."
19.32: "Therefore this is what the LORD says concerning the king of Assyria: 'Not only will he not approach this city or shoot an arrow in its direction, he won't approach it with so much as a shield, nor will he throw up a siege ramp against it.
19.33: He'll return on the same route by which he came—he won't come to this city,' declares the LORD.
19.34: I will defend this city and preserve it for my own reasons, and because of my servant David.'"
19.35: That very night, the angel of the LORD went out to the camp of the Assyrian army and killed 185,000 men. Early the next morning, when the army of Israel arose, all 185,000 soldiers were dead.
19.36: As a result, King Sennacherib of Assyria left and returned to Nineveh where he lived.
19.37: Later on, as he was worshiping in the temple of his god Nisroch, Adrammelech and Sharezer killed him with a sword and fled into the territory of Ararat. Then Sennacherib's son Esarhaddon became king in his place.

20.1: During this time, Hezekiah became sick with a fatal illness, so Isaiah the prophet, the son of Amoz, approached him and told him, "This is what the LORD says: 'Put your household in order, because you are dying. You will not survive.'"
20.2: So Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed to the LORD.
20.3: "Remember me, LORD," he said, "how I have walked in your presence with integrity, with an undivided heart, and I have accomplished what is good in your sight." And Hezekiah wept deeply.
20.4: Before Isaiah had left the middle court, this message from the LORD came to him.
20.5: "Return to Hezekiah," he said, "and tell the Commander-in-Chief of my people: 'This is what the LORD, the God of your ancestor David, says: "I've heard your prayer and I've observed your tears. Look! I'm healing you. Three days from now, you'll go visit the LORD's Temple.
20.6: Furthermore, I'll add fifteen years to your life. I'll deliver you and this city from domination by the king of Assyria, and I'll defend this city for my own sake and for the sake of my servant David."'"
20.7: Isaiah said, "Take a fig cake." So some attendants took it, laid it on Hezekiah's boil, and he recovered.
20.8: Now Hezekiah had asked Isaiah, "What is to be the sign that the LORD is healing me and that I'll be going up to the LORD's Temple three days from now?"
20.9: So Isaiah replied, "This will be your sign from the LORD that the LORD will do what he has promised. Shall the shadow go forward ten steps or go back ten steps?"
20.10: Hezekiah answered, "It's an easy thing for a shadow to lengthen ten steps. So let the shadow go backward ten steps."
20.11: So Isaiah cried out to the LORD, who brought the shadow back ten steps after it had gone down the stairway of Ahaz.
20.12: Some time later, Berodach-baladan, the son of King Baladan of Babylon, sent letters and a gift to Hezekiah, because he had heard that Hezekiah had been ill.
20.13: Hezekiah listened to the entourage and showed them his entire treasury, including the silver, gold, and spices, the precious oil, his armory, and everything that was inventoried in his treasuries. There was nothing in his household or in his holdings that Hezekiah did not show them.
20.14: Then Isaiah the prophet came to King Hezekiah and asked him, "What did these men have to say, and where did they come from?" Hezekiah replied, "They came from a country far away—from Babylon."
20.15: He asked, "What did they see in your household?" Hezekiah answered, "They have seen everything. In my household there is nothing in my treasuries that I haven't shown them."
20.16: Then Isaiah replied to Hezekiah, "Listen to this message from the LORD:
20.17: Watch out! The days are coming when everything that's in your house—everything that your ancestors have saved up right to this day—will be carried off to Babylon. Nothing will be left,' declares the LORD.
20.18: Some of your descendants—your very own seed, whom you will father—will be carried away to become officials in the palace of the king of Babylon.'"
20.19: At this, Hezekiah replied to Isaiah, "What you've spoken from the LORD is good," because he had been thinking, "Why not, as long as there's peace and security in my lifetime…?"
20.20: Now the rest of Hezekiah's actions, as well as his glorious deeds, including how he constructed the pool and the conduit to bring water into the city, are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah, are they not?
20.21: Hezekiah died, as did his ancestors, and his son Manasseh became king in his place.

21.1: Manasseh began to reign at the age of twelve, and he reigned for 55 years in Jerusalem. His mother was named Hephzibah.
21.2: He did what the LORD considered to be evil, following the despicable practices of the nations whom the LORD had expelled in full view of the people of Israel.
21.3: He rebuilt the high places that his father Hezekiah had destroyed. He erected altars for Baal, crafted an Asherah, just as King Ahab of Israel had done, and worshipped and served the stars of heaven.
21.4: He also built altars in the LORD's Temple, about which the LORD had said, "In Jerusalem I will place my Name."
21.5: He built two altars to every star in the heavens in the two courts of the LORD's Temple.
21.6: He made his son into a burnt offering, practiced witchcraft, used divination, and consorted with mediums and spirit-channelers. He practiced many things that the LORD considered to be evil and provoked him.
21.7: He also erected the carved image of Asherah that he had made inside the Temple about which the LORD had spoken to David and to his son Solomon, "I will put my Name forever in this Temple and in Jerusalem, which I have chosen from all of the tribes of Israel.
21.8: And I will not make Israel's feet to wander anymore from the land that I have given to their ancestors, if they will only be careful to do everything that I have commanded them according to the entire Law that my servant Moses commanded them."
21.9: But they would not listen. Manasseh led them astray to practice more evil than the nations whom the LORD had destroyed in the presence of the Israelis.
21.10: So the LORD announced through his prophets,
21.11: "Because King Manasseh of Judah has committed these despicable things, acting more sinfully than did all of the Amorites who preceded him, including making Judah sin with its idols,
21.12: therefore this is what the LORD God of Israel says: 'Look! I'm going to bring such a disaster to Jerusalem and Judah that both ears of those who hear about it will ring.
21.13: I'll stretch out over Jerusalem the measuring line that is Samaria and the plumb line that is Ahab's dynasty. Then I'll wipe Jerusalem like one wipes a dish, wiping it and turning it upside down!
21.14: I will abandon the survivors of my heritage and hand them over to their enemies. They will become war booty and spoil to all of their enemies,
21.15: because they have done what I consider to be evil and they have provoked me from the day their ancestors left Egypt right up to this day!'"
21.16: In addition to this, Manasseh shed lots of innocent blood—until he had filled Jerusalem from one end to another—besides his sin by which he caused Judah to sin by practicing what the LORD considered to be evil.
21.17: The rest of Manasseh's deeds, including everything that he accomplished and the sin that he practiced, are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah, are they not?
21.18: Manasseh died, as did his ancestors, and he was buried in the garden at his home in the Garden of Uzza. His son Amon became king in his place.
21.19: Amon began to reign at the age of 22, and ruled for two years in Jerusalem. His mother was named Meshullemeth, the daughter of Haruz of Jotbah.
21.20: He practiced what the LORD considered to be evil, just as his father Manasseh had done,
21.21: because he completely adopted his father's lifestyle, serving the same idols his father had served and worshipped.
21.22: As a result, he abandoned the LORD God of his ancestors and did not walk in the LORD's way.
21.23: Later on, Amon's staff conspired against him and killed the king inside his own home.
21.24: But afterward, the people of the land executed everyone who had conspired against King Amon, and the people of the land installed his son Josiah to be king in his place.
21.25: Now the rest of Amon's activities that he undertook are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah, are they not?
21.26: He was buried in his own grave in the Garden of Uzza, and his son Josiah became king in his place.

22.1: Josiah was an eight year old child when he began to reign, and he reigned for 31 years in Jerusalem. His mother was named Jedidah, the daughter of Adaiah of Bozkath.
22.2: He practiced what the LORD considered to be right, living the way his ancestor David had lived, turning neither to the right nor to the left.
22.3: Eighteen years after King Josiah had begun to reign, the king sent Azaliah's son Shaphan, grandson of Meshullam the scribe, to the LORD's Temple. He told him,
22.4: "Go to the high priest Hilkiah, so he can count the money that has been brought into the LORD's Temple by the doorkeepers who have been gathering it from the people.
22.5: Have them deliver it to the workmen who are supervising the LORD's Temple, so that they may pay it over to the workmen who serve in the LORD's Temple to repair its damages,
22.6: including paying the carpenters, builders, and masons, as well as buying timber and pre-carved stone to repair the Temple.
22.7: But you won't need to force them to be accountable for money already paid to them, since they're faithful."
22.8: Later on, Hilkiah the high priest informed Shaphan the scribe, "I've discovered the Book of the Law in the LORD's Temple." Hilkiah gave the book to Shaphan, and he began to read it.
22.9: Shaphan the scribe reported to King Josiah, brought up the matter to him, and told him, "Your servants have distributed the money that was found in the Temple by giving it to the workmen who supervise the LORD's Temple."
22.10: Then Shaphan the scribe informed the king, "Hilkiah the priest has given me a book." Then Shaphan read from it in the king's presence.
22.11: When the king heard what was written in the Book of the Law, he tore his clothes
22.12: and issued these orders to Hilkiah the priest, Shaphan's son Ahikam, Micaiah's son Achbor, Shaphan the scribe, and the king's servant Asaiah:
22.13: "Go ask the LORD for me, for the people, and for all of Judah about what's written in this book that has been discovered, because the LORD's anger is burning against us, since our ancestors have not listened to the words written in this book and have not lived according to everything that is written concerning us."
22.14: So Hilkiah the priest, Ahikam, Achbor, Shaphan, and Asaiah went to the prophet Huldah, the wife of Tikvah's son Shallum, the grandson of Harhas and supervisor of the royal wardrobe, who lived in the Second Quarter in Jerusalem. They spoke with her,
22.15: and she told them, "This is what the LORD God of Israel says: 'Tell the man who sent you to me:
22.16: "This is what the Lord says: 'Look! I'm bringing disaster on this place and on its inhabitants—everything written in the book that the king of Judah has read—
22.17: because they have abandoned me, burned incense to other gods, and they have provoked me to anger with everything that they've done. Therefore my anger is kindled against this place and it won't be quenched!'"
22.18: Nevertheless, tell the king of Judah who sent you to ask the LORD about this, "This is what the LORD God of Israel says: 'Now about what you've heard,
22.19: because your heart was sensitive, and you humbled yourself in the LORD's presence when you heard what I had to say against this place and against its inhabitants—that they would become a desolation and a curse—and you have torn your clothes and cried out before me, be assured that I have truly heard you,' declares the LORD.
22.20: Therefore, look! I will gather you to your ancestors, and you will be placed in your grave in peace. Your eyes will never see all the evil that I will bring on this place.'"'"

23.1: At this, the king sent for and gathered together all the elders of Judah and Jerusalem.
23.2: The king went up to the LORD's Temple, accompanied by all the men of Judah, everyone who lived in Jerusalem, the priests, the prophets, and everyone—including those who were unimportant and those who were important—and he read to them everything written in the Book of the Covenant that had been discovered in the LORD's Temple.
23.3: The king stood beside a pillar and made a covenant in the presence of the LORD: to follow after the LORD, to keep his commandments, his testimonies, and his statutes with all of his heart and soul, and to carry out what was written in the covenant contained in the book. All the people consented to enter into the covenant.
23.4: The king ordered Hilkiah the high priest, the priests of the secondary order, and the doorkeepers to take out of the LORD's Temple all of the implements that had been crafted for Baal, for Asherah, and for every star in the heavens. Then he burned them outside Jerusalem in the fields of the Kidron and carried the ashes to Bethel.
23.5: The king unseated the idolatrous priests whom the kings of Judah had appointed to burn incense in the high places throughout the cities of Judah and in the environs surrounding Jerusalem, including those who had been burning incense to Baal, to the sun, to the moon, to the constellations, and to every star in the heavens.
23.6: He brought the Asherah from the LORD's Temple to the Kidron Brook outside Jerusalem, burned it at the Kidron brook, pulverized the ashes to dust, and scattered it over the graves of the common people.
23.7: He also demolished the temples of the cultic male prostitutes that had been operating in the LORD's Temple, where the women had been doing weaving for the Asherah.
23.8: Then he gathered together all the priests from the cities of Judah and defiled the high places from Geba to Beer-sheba, where the priests had burned incense. He also demolished the high places of the gates that had been erected to the left as one enters the city gate—that is, near the entrance operated by Joshua, the governor of the city.
23.9: Nevertheless, the priests of the high places did not approach the LORD's altar in Jerusalem, but instead they ate unleavened bread given to them by their relatives.
23.10: He also defiled Topheth, which is located in the Ben-hinnom Valley, so that no one would force his son or daughter to pass through the fire in dedication to Molech.
23.11: He abolished the horses that the kings of Judah had dedicated to the sun at the entrance to the LORD's Temple, near the offices of Nathan-melech, the official, that were in the precincts. He also set fire to the chariots of the sun.
23.12: The king demolished the rooftop altars on top of Ahaz's upper chamber that the kings of Judah had erected, as well as the altars that Manasseh had made in the two courts of the LORD's Temple. He pulverized them where they stood and cast their dust into the Kidron Brook.
23.13: The king defiled the high places which faced Jerusalem on the south side of Corruption Mountain, which King Solomon of Israel had constructed for Ashtoreth, the Sidonian abomination, for Chemosh, the Moabite abomination, and for Milcom, the Ammonite abomination.
23.14: He broke the pillars to pieces, cut down the Asherim, and filled their locations with human bones.
23.15: Furthermore, he even broke down the altar that had been at Bethel as well as the high place constructed by Nebat's son Jeroboam, who had caused Israel to sin. He demolished its stones, pulverized them to dust, and burned the Asherah.
23.16: As Josiah turned around, he observed the graves located there on the mountain, so he sent for and recovered the bones from the graves and burned them on the altar to defile it, in keeping with the message from the LORD that the godly man had proclaimed when he was declaring these things.
23.17: He asked, "What is this monument that I'm looking at?" The men who lived in that city answered him, "It's the grave of that godly man who came from Judah and predicted these things that you've done against the altar at Bethel!"
23.18: Josiah replied, "Leave him alone. No one is to disturb his bones." So they preserved his bones undisturbed, along with the bones of the prophet who had come from Samaria.
23.19: Josiah also removed all of the temples on the high places that had been in the cities of Samaria and that the kings of Israel had erected, thereby provoking the LORD. He treated Samaria just as he had Bethel.
23.20: After he had slaughtered all the priests who served at the high places and burned their bones on those high places, he returned to Jerusalem.
23.21: After this, the king commanded all of the people, "Celebrate the Passover to the LORD your God, just as it's prescribed in this Book of the Covenant."
23.22: From the days of the judges who ruled in Israel, no Passover had been celebrated like this, not even in all the reigns of the kings of Israel and the kings of Judah.
23.23: In the eighteenth year of the reign of King Josiah, this Passover was observed in Jerusalem to honor the LORD.
23.24: Furthermore, Josiah removed the mediums, the necromancers, the household gods, the idols, and every despicable thing that could be seen in the territory of Judah and in Jerusalem, so that he might confirm the words of the Law that had been written in the book that Hilkiah the priest had discovered in the LORD's Temple.
23.25: There had been no king like him before him, who turned to the LORD with all his heart, with all his soul, and with all his strength, in obeying everything in the Law of Moses. No king arose like Josiah after him.
23.26: Even so, the LORD did not turn away from his fierce and great anger that burned against Judah because of everything with which Manasseh had provoked him.
23.27: The LORD said, "I'm going to remove Judah from my sight as well, just as I've removed Israel. I will abandon Jerusalem, this city that I've chosen, as well as the Temple, about which I've spoken, 'My Name shall remain there.'"
23.28: Now the rest of Josiah's actions, including everything that he did, are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah, are they not?
23.29: During his reign, Pharaoh Neco, king of Egypt, marched out toward the Euphrates River to meet the king of Assyria. King Josiah went out to engage him in battle, but Pharaoh Neco killed him at Megiddo as soon as he saw him.
23.30: Josiah's servants drove his corpse in a chariot from Megiddo to Jerusalem and buried him in a tomb made for him. The people of the land took Josiah's son Jehoahaz, anointed him, and installed him as king in his father's place.
23.31: Jehoahaz was 23 years old when he became king. He reigned three months in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Hamutal. She was the daughter of Jeremiah of Libnah.
23.32: He practiced what the LORD considered to be evil, just as all of his ancestors had done.
23.33: Pharaoah Neco placed him in custody at Riblah, in the land of Hamath, so that he would not reign in Jerusalem, and imposed a tribute of 100 talents of silver and a talent of gold.
23.34: Pharaoh Neco installed Josiah's son Eliakim as king to replace his father Josiah and changed his name to Jehoiakim. He transported Jehoahaz off to Egypt, where he died.
23.35: As a result, Jehoiakim paid the silver and gold tribute to Pharaoh, but he passed on the costs to the inhabitants of the land in taxes, in keeping with Pharaoh's orders. He exacted the silver and gold from the people who lived in the land, from each according to his assessment, in order to pay it to Pharaoh Neco.
23.36: Jehoiakim was 25 years old when he became king, and he reigned for eleven years in Jerusalem. His mother was named Zebidah. She was the daughter of Pedaiah of Rumah.
23.37: Eliakim practiced what the LORD considered to be evil, just as his ancestors had done.

24.1: During his lifetime, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon attacked Jehoiakim, who became his vassal for three years, after which he turned against Nebuchadnezzar and rebelled.
24.2: The LORD sent raiding parties from the Chaldeans, Arameans, Moabites, and Ammonites against Jehoiakim. He sent them against Judah to destroy it, in keeping with the message from the LORD that he had spoken through his servants, the prophets.
24.3: It was truly by the command of the LORD against Judah that it came, in order to remove them from his sight, because of every sin that Manasseh had committed,
24.4: as well as for the innocent blood that he had shed. He had filled Jerusalem with innocent blood, and the LORD would not forgive them.
24.5: Now the rest of Jehoiakim's actions, and everything that he undertook, are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah, are they not?
24.6: Jehoiakim died, as did his ancestors, and his son Jehoiachin became king in his place.
24.7: The king of Egypt did not leave his territory again, because the king of Babylon had taken everything that belonged to the king of Egypt from the Wadi of Egypt to the Euphrates River.
24.8: Jehoiachin became king at the age of eighteen years, and he reigned for three months in Jerusalem. His mother was named Hausa. She was the daughter of Elzaphan of Jerusalem.
24.9: He practiced what the LORD considered to be evil, just as his ancestors had done.
24.10: At that time, the servants of King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon attacked Jerusalem and the city was placed under siege.
24.11: King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon came up against the city, along with his servants, who besieged it.
24.12: King Jehoiachin of Judah surrendered to the king of Babylon (as did his mother, his servants, his princes, and his officers) during the eighth year of his reign.
24.13: Nebuchadnezzar carried off from there all of the treasures of the LORD's Temple, along with the treasures in the king's palace. He cut into pieces all the gold vessels in the LORD's Temple that King Solomon of Israel had made, just as the LORD had said would happen.
24.14: Then Nebuchadnezzar sent away into exile all of Jerusalem—all the captains, all the valiant soldiers, 10,000 captives, and all of the craftsmen and ironworkers. Nobody remained except the poorest people of the land.
24.15: He sent Jehoiachin into exile to Babylon, along with the king's mother, the king's wives, his officials, and the leading men of the land. He took them into exile from Jerusalem to Babylon.
24.16: All 7,000 of the most valiant soldiers and 1,000 of the craftsmen and ironworkers—all physically fit and trained for battle—were brought by the king of Babylon into exile in Babylon.
24.17: The king of Babylon installed Jehoiachin's uncle Mattaniah as king in his place and then changed his name to Zedekiah.
24.18: Zedekiah was 21 years old when he became king. He reigned for eleven years in Jerusalem. His mother was named Hamutal. She was the daughter of Jeremiah of Libnah.
24.19: Zedekiah practiced what the LORD considered to be evil, just as Jehoiakim had done,
24.20: because through the LORD's anger these things happened to Jerusalem and Judah until he threw them from his presence. Zedekiah then rebelled against the king of Babylon,

25.1: so on the tenth day of the tenth month of the ninth year of Zedekiah's reign, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon and his entire army approached Jerusalem, attacked it, encamped against it, and built a siege wall that surrounded the city.
25.2: The city remained under siege until the eleventh year of the reign of King Zedekiah.
25.3: By the ninth day of the fourth month, the resulting famine had become so severe in the city that no food remained for the people who lived in the land.
25.4: The city was breached, and the entire army left during the night through the gate that stood between the two walls beside the royal garden, even though the Chaldeans had surrounded the city. They escaped through the Arabah,
25.5: but the Chaldean army pursued the king and overtook him in the Jericho plains, where his entire army was scattered.
25.6: The Chaldeans captured the king and brought him to Riblah, where the king of Babylon determined his sentence.
25.7: They executed Zedekiah's sons in his presence, blinded Zedekiah, bound him with bronze chains, and transported him to Babylon.
25.8: On the seventh day of the fifth month, which was during the nineteenth year of King Nebuchadnezzar's reign as king of Babylon, captain of the guard Nebuzaradan, a servant of the king of Babylon, arrived in Jerusalem
25.9: and set fire to the LORD's Temple, the royal palace, and all the houses of Jerusalem. He even incinerated the lavish homes.
25.10: The Chaldean army that accompanied the captain of the guard demolished the walls that surrounded Jerusalem.
25.11: Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, carried the survivors of the people who remained in the city, those who had deserted to the king of Babylon, and the rest of the multitude into exile.
25.12: However, the captain of the guard left some of the poor people of the land to work as vinedressers and farmers.
25.13: The Chaldeans also broke into pieces and carried back to Babylon the bronze pillars that stood in the LORD's Temple, along with the stands and the bronze sea that used to be in the LORD's Temple.
25.14: They also confiscated the pots, shovels, snuffers, spoons, and the rest of the bronze vessels that were used in ministry.
25.15: The captain of the guard also confiscated the fire pans, basins, and whatever had been crafted of pure gold and pure silver.
25.16: The bronze contained in the two pillars, the one sea, and the stands that Solomon had crafted for the LORD's Temple could not be inventoried for weight.
25.17: The height of one of the pillars was eighteen cubits, and the capital on top of it was three cubits high. A latticework carved in the form of pomegranates encircled the capital, crafted completely out of brass. The second pillar was identical to the first.
25.18: The captain of the guard arrested Seraiah the chief priest, Zephaniah the second priest, three temple officials,
25.19: one overseer from the city who supervised the soldiers, five of the king's advisors who had been discovered in the city, the scribe who served the army captain who mustered the army of the land, and 60 men of the land who were discovered in the city.
25.20: Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, took them to the king of Babylon at Riblah,
25.21: where the king of Babylon executed them in the land of Hamath. And so Judah was transported into exile from the land.
25.22: Now as for the people who remained in the land of Judah whom King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon had left behind, he appointed Ahikam's son Gedaliah, the grandson of Shaphan, to rule.
25.23: When all the captains of the armies, along with their men, heard that the king of Babylon had appointed Gedaliah, these men visited Gedaliah at Mizpah: Nethaniah's son Ishmael, Kareah's son Johanan, Tanhumeth the Netophathite's son Seraiah, and Jaazaniah, who was descended from the Maacathites.
25.24: Gedaliah made this promise to them and to their men: "Don't be afraid of the servants of the Chaldeans. Live in the land and serve the king of Babylon, and things will go well with you."
25.25: Nevertheless, seven months later, Nethaniah's son Ishmael, the grandson of Elishama from the royal family, came with ten men and attacked Gedaliah. As a result, he died along with the Jews and Chaldeans who were with him at Mizpah.
25.26: Then all the people, including those who were insignificant and those who were important, fled with the captains of the armed forces to Egypt, because they were afraid of the Chaldeans.
25.27: Later on, after King Jehoiachin of Judah had been in exile for 37 years, on the twenty-seventh day of the twelfth month, during the first year of his reign, King Evil-merodach of Babylon released King Jehoiachin of Judah from prison.
25.28: He spoke kindly to him and elevated his position above the thrones of the kings with him in Babylon.
25.29: Jehoiachin changed out of his prison clothes and had regular meals in the king's presence every day for the rest of his life,
25.30: and a regular stipend was provided to him by the king in accordance with his needs for as long as he lived.

1.1: Adam fathered Seth, who fathered Enosh,
1.2: who fathered Kenan, who fathered Mahalalel, who fathered Jared,
1.3: who fathered Enoch, who fathered Methuselah, who fathered Lamech,
1.4: who fathered Noah, who fathered Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
1.5: Japheth's descendants were Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.
1.6: Gomer's descendants were Ashkenaz, Diphath, and Togarmah.
1.7: Javan's descendants were Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim, and Rodanim.
1.8: Ham's descendants were Cush, Mizraim, Put, and Canaan.
1.9: Cush's descendants were Seba, Havilah, Sabta, Raama, and Sabteca. Raamah's descendants were Sheba and Dedan.
1.10: Cush fathered Nimrod. He became the first powerful ruler on the earth.
1.11: Mitzraim fathered the Ludim, the Anamim, the Lehabim, the Naphtuhim,
1.12: the Pathrusim, the Casluhim (from whom the Philistines descended) , and the Caphtorim.
1.13: Canaan fathered Sidon his firstborn, as well as Heth,
1.14: and the Jebusites, the Amorites, the Girgashites,
1.15: the Hivites, the Archites, the Sinites,
1.16: the Arvadites, the Zemarites, and the Hamathites.
1.17: Shem's descendants were Elam, Asshur, Arpachshad, Lud, Aram, Uz, Hul, Gether, and Meshech.
1.18: Arpachshad fathered Shelah and Shelah fathered Eber.
1.19: Eber fathered two sons. The name of the one was Peleg (because the earth was divided during his lifetime) and his brother was named Joktan.
1.20: Joktan fathered Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,
1.23: Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab—all of these were Joktan's descendants.
1.24: In summary, Shem fathered Arpachshad, who fathered Shelah,
1.25: who fathered Eber, who fathered Peleg, who fathered Reu,
1.26: who fathered Serug, who fathered Nahor, who fathered Terah,
1.28: Abraham's descendants were Isaac and Ishmael.
1.29: These are their genealogies: the firstborn Ishmael fathered Nebaioth, and then Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,
1.31: Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah—these are the Ishmaelites.
1.32: The descendants born to Keturah, Abraham's mistress, were Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah. The descendants of Jokshan were Sheba and Dedan.
1.33: The descendants of Midian were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah. All these were the descendants of Keturah.
1.34: Abraham fathered Isaac. Isaac's descendants were Esau and Israel.
1.35: Esau's descendants were Eliphaz, Reuel, Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.
1.36: Eliphaz's descendants were Teman, Omar, Zephi, Gatam, Kenaz, Timna, and Amalek.
1.37: Reuel's descendants were Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah.
1.38: Seir's descendants were Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah, Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan.
1.39: Lotan's descendants were Hori and Homam. Lotan's sister was Timna.
1.40: Shobal's descendants were Alian, Manahath, Ebal, Shephi, and Onam. Zibeon's descendants were Aiah and Anah.
1.41: Anah's descendant was Dishon. Dishon's descendants were Hamran, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran.
1.42: Ezer's descendants were Bilhan, Zaavan, and Jaakan. Dishan's descendants were Uz and Aran.
1.43: Here's a list of kings who reigned in the land of Edom before any king reigned over the Israelis, beginning with Beor's son Bela (his city was named Dinhabah).
1.44: After Bela died, Zerah's son Jobab from Bozrah succeeded him.
1.45: After Jobab died, Husham from the land of the Temanites succeeded him.
1.46: After Husham died, Bedad's son Hadad, who defeated Midian in the country of Moab, succeeded him. His city was named Avith.
1.47: After Hadad died, Samlah from Masrekah succeeded him.
1.48: After Samlah died, Shaul from Rehoboth on the Euphrates River succeeded him.
1.49: After Shaul died, Achbor's son Baal-hanan succeeded him.
1.50: After Baal-hanan died, Hadad succeeded him. His city was named Pai, and his wife's name was Mehetabel. She was the daughter of Matred, who was the daughter of Me-zahab.
1.51: Then Hadad died. The chiefs of Edom included the chiefs of Timna, Aliah, Jetheth,
1.54: Magdiel, and Iram—these are the clans of Edom.

2.1: Here's a list of Israel's sons: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Zebulun,
2.2: Dan, Joseph, Benjamin, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.
2.3: Judah's three sons Er, Onan, and Shelah were born to him through Bath-shua, a Canaanite. Er, Judah's firstborn, became wicked in the LORD's sight, so he put him to death.
2.4: Judah's daughter-in-law Tamar also bore him Perez and Zerah, so Judah had five sons in all.
2.5: Perez's sons were Hezron and Hamul.
2.6: Zerah had five sons in all: Zimri, Ethan, Heman, Calcol, and Dara.
2.7: Carmi's son was Achar, who became Israel's troublemaker by transgressing the LORD's commandment regarding things that were to be destroyed.
2.8: Ethan's son was Azariah.
2.9: Hezron's sons born to him were Jerahmeel, Ram, and Chelubai.
2.10: Ram fathered Amminadab, and Amminadab fathered Nahshon, who was leader of the descendants of Judah.
2.11: Nahshon fathered Salma, Salma fathered Boaz,
2.12: Boaz fathered Obed, and Obed fathered Jesse.
2.13: Jesse fathered Eliab his firstborn, Abinadab his second born, Shimea his third born,
2.14: Nethanel his fourth born, Raddai his fifth born,
2.15: Ozem his sixth born, David his seventh born;
2.16: along with their sisters Zeruiah and Abigail. Zeruiah's three sons were Abishai, Joab, and Asahel.
2.17: Abigail bore Amasa, whose father was Jether the Ishmaelite.
2.18: Hezron's son Caleb had children by his wife Azubah and by Jerioth. These were her sons: Jesher, Shobab, and Ardon.
2.19: When Azubah died, Caleb married Ephrath, who bore him Hur.
2.20: Hur fathered Uri, and Uri fathered Bezalel.
2.21: Later, Hezron married the daughter of Machir, who had fathered Gilead. He married her when he was 60 years old, and she bore him Segub.
2.22: Segub fathered Jair, who had 23 towns in the land of Gilead.
2.23: But Geshur and Aram took 60 towns from Gilead, including Havvoth-jair and Kenath, along with their villages. All these were descendants of Machir, who fathered Gilead.
2.24: After Hezron died in Caleb-ephrathah, Abijah wife of Hezron bore him Ashhur, who fathered Tekoa.
2.25: The descendants of Jerahmeel, the firstborn of Hezron, were Ram his firstborn, Bunah, Oren, Ozem, and Ahijah.
2.26: Jerahmeel also had another wife, whose name was Atarah; she was the mother of Onam.
2.27: The descendants of Ram, firstborn of Jerahmeel were Maaz, Jamin, and Eker.
2.28: Onam's descendants were Shammai and Jada. Shammai's descendants were Nadab and Abishur.
2.29: Abishur's wife was named Abihail. She bore him Ahban and Molid.
2.30: Nadab's descendants were Seled and Appaim. Seled died childless.
2.31: Appaim's son was Ishi. Ishi's son was Sheshan. Sheshan's son was Ahlai.
2.32: Shammai's brother Jada's descendants were Jether and Jonathan, but Jether died childless.
2.33: Jonathan's descendants were Peleth and Zaza. These were the descendants of Jerahmeel.
2.34: Now Sheshan had no sons, only daughters. However, Sheshan had an Egyptian slave named Jarha.
2.35: So Sheshan gave his daughter in marriage to his slave Jarha, and she bore him Attai.
2.36: Attai fathered Nathan, and Nathan fathered Zabad.
2.37: Zabad fathered Ephlal, Ephlal fathered Obed,
2.38: Obed fathered Jehu, Jehu fathered Azariah,
2.39: Azariah fathered Helez, Helez fathered Eleasah,
2.40: Eleasah fathered Sismai, Sismai fathered Shallum.
2.41: Shallum fathered Jekamiah, and Jekamiah fathered Elishama.
2.42: Jerahmeel's brother Caleb's descendants were his firstborn Mesha, who fathered Ziph. The descendants of Mareshah, who fathered Hebron, were as follows:
2.43: Hebron's descendants were Korah, Tappuah, Rekem, and Shema.
2.44: Shema fathered Raham, who fathered Jorkeam. Rekem fathered Shammai.
2.45: Shammai's descendants included Maon, who fathered Beth-zur.
2.46: Caleb's mistress Ephah also bore Haran, Moza, and Gazez. Haran fathered Gazez.
2.47: Jahdai's descendants were Regem, Jotham, Geshan, Pelet, Ephah, and Shaaph.
2.48: Caleb's mistress Maacah bore Sheber, Tirhanah,
2.49: and Shaaph, who fathered Madmannah. Sheva fathered Machbenah and Gibe. Caleb's daughter was Achsah.
2.50: These were Caleb's descendants. The son? of Hur, the firstborn of Ephrathah, was Shobal, who fathered Kiriath-jearim,
2.51: Salma, who fathered Bethlehem, and Hareph, who fathered Beth-gader.
2.52: Shobal, who fathered Kiriath-jearim, had other sons, including Haroeh, half of the Menuhoth.
2.53: The families of Kiriath-jearim included the Ithrites, the Puthites, the Shumathites, and the Mishraites. The Zorathites and the Eshtaolites came from them.
2.54: Salma's descendants were Bethlehem, the Netophathites, Atroth-beth-joab, and half of the Manahathites, the Zorites.
2.55: The families of the scribes who lived at Jabez included the Tirathites, the Shimeathites, and the Sucathites. These are the Kenites who came from Hammath, who fathered the house of Rechab.

3.1: These are David's descendants who were born to him in Hebron: Amnon his firstborn by Ahinoam the Jezreelite, Daniel his second born by Abigail the Carmelite,
3.2: Absalom his third born by Maacah daughter of King Talmai of Geshur, Adonijah his fourth born by Haggith,
3.3: Shephatiah his fifth born by Abital, and Ithream his sixth born by his wife Eglah.
3.4: These six were born to him in Hebron, where he reigned for seven years and six months. He reigned 33 years in Jerusalem.
3.5: These four children were born to David by Bath-shua daughter of Ammiel while he was living in Jerusalem: Shimea, Shobab, Nathan, and Solomon,
3.6: followed by nine more: Ibhar, Elishama, Eliphelet,
3.7: Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia,
3.8: Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.
3.9: All these were David's sons, besides children born to his mistresses. Tamar was their sister.
3.10: Solomon's descendants included Rehoboam, his son Abijah, his son Asa, his son Jehoshaphat,
3.11: his son Joram, his son Ahaziah, his son Joash,
3.12: his son Amaziah, his son Azariah, his son Jotham,
3.13: his son Ahaz, his son Hezekiah, his son Manasseh,
3.14: his son Amon, and his son Josiah.
3.15: Josiah's descendants included Johanan his firstborn, his second born Jehoiakim, his third born Zedekiah, and his fourth born Shallum.
3.16: Jehoiakim's descendants included his son Jeconiah, and his son Zedekiah.
3.17: The descendants of Jeconiah, who was taken captive to Babylon , included his son Shealtiel,
3.18: Malchiram, Pedaiah, Shenazzar, Jekamiah, Hoshama, and Nedabiah.
3.19: Pedaiah's descendants included Zerubbabel and Shimei. Zerubbabel's descendants included Meshullam and Hananiah, along with Shelomith their sister
3.20: and five others: Hashubah, Ohel, Berechiah, Hasadiah, and Jushab-hesed.
3.21: Hananiah's descendants included Pelatiah and Jeshaiah, his son Rephaiah, his son Arnan, his son Obadiah, and his son Shecaniah.
3.22: Shecaniah's son was Shemaiah, and the six sons of Shemaiah were Hattush, Igal, Bariah, Neariah, and Shaphat.
3.23: The three sons of Neariah were Elioenai, Hizkiah, and Azrikam.
3.24: The seven sons of Elioenai were Hodaviah, Eliashib, Pelaiah, Akkub, Johanan, Delaiah, and Anani.

4.1: Judah's descendants were Perez, Hezron, Carmi, Hur, and Shobal.
4.2: Shobal's son Reaiah fathered Jahath, and Jahath fathered Ahumai and Lahad. These were the families of the Zorathites.
4.3: These were the descendants of the ancestor of Etam: Jezreel, Ishma, and Idbash; and their sister's name was Hazzelelponi.
4.4: Penuel fathered Gedor and Ezer fathered Hushah. These were the descendants of Hur, Ephrathah's firstborn, who fathered Bethlehem:
4.5: Tekoa's father Ashhur had two wives, Helah and Naarah.
4.6: Naarah bore him these sons: Ahuzzam, Hepher, Temeni, and Haahashtari.
4.7: The sons of Helah were Zereth, Izhar, and Ethnan.
4.8: Koz fathered Anub, Zobebah, and the families of Harum's son Aharhel.
4.9: Jabez enjoyed more honor than his relatives—his mother named him Jabez, she said, "because I bore him in pain."
4.10: Later on, Jabez called on the God of Israel, asking him, "…whether you would bless me again and again, enlarge my territory, keep your power with me, keep me from evil, and keep me from harm!" And God granted what he had requested.
4.11: Chelub, Shuhah's brother, fathered Mehir, who fathered Eshton.
4.12: Eshton fathered Beth-rapha, Paseah, and Tehinnah, who fathered Ir-nahash. These are the men of Recah.
4.13: Kenaz's descendants were Othniel and Seraiah. Othniel's descendants were Hathath
4.14: and Meonothai, who fathered Ophrah. Seraiah fathered Joab, who fathered the Ge-harashim, because they became artisans.
4.15: The descendants of Jephunneh's son Caleb were Iru, Elah, and Naam. Elah's son was Kenaz.
4.16: Jehallelel's descendants were Ziph, Ziphah, Tiria, and Asarel.
4.17: Ezrah's descendants were Jether, Mered, Epher, and Jalon. Mered's wife conceived Miriam, Shammai, and Ishbah, who fathered Eshtemoa.
4.18: Then his Judean wife bore Jered, who fathered Gedor and then Heber, who fathered Soco and Jekuthiel, who fathered Zanoah. These are the descendants of Bithiah, daughter of Pharaoh, whom Mered married.
4.19: The descendants of Hodiah's wife, Naham's sister, fathered Keilah the Garmite and Eshtemoa the Maacathite.
4.20: Shimon's descendants were Amnon, Rinnah, Ben-hanan, and Tilon. Ishi's descendants were Zoheth and Ben-zoheth.
4.21: The descendants of Judah's son Shelah were Er, who fathered Lecah, Laadah (who fathered Mareshah and the families who belonged to the guild of linen workers at Beth-ashbea),
4.22: Jokim, the men who lived in Cozeba, Joash, and Saraph (who married Moabite families), and Jashubi-lehem. (The records are ancient.)
4.23: These people were potters who lived in Netaim and Gederah in service to their king, who lived there.
4.24: Simeon's descendants were Nemuel, Jamin, Jarib, Zerah, Shaul,?
4.25: his son Shallum, his son Mibsam, and his son Mishma.
4.26: Mishma's descendants were his son Hammuel, his son Zaccur, and his son Shimei.
4.27: Shimei had 16 sons and six daughters, but his relatives did not have many children, nor did their entire family multiply like the Judeans did.
4.28: They lived in Beer-sheba, Moladah, Hazar-shual,
4.31: Beth-marcaboth, Hazar-susim, Beth-biri, and Shaaraim. These were their cities until David began to reign.
4.32: Their cities were Etam, Ain, Rimmon, Tochen, and Ashan, for a total of five cities,
4.33: along with all their settlements that surrounded these cities as far as Baal—this is their settlement history. They kept this genealogical record for themselves:
4.35: Joel, Joshibiah's son Jehu (who was the grandson of Seraiah and great-grandson of Asiel),
4.36: Elioenai, Jaakobah, Jeshohaiah, Asaiah, Adiel, Jesimiel, Benaiah,
4.37: Shiphi's son Ziza (who was the grandson of Shiphi, who was fathered by Allon, who was fathered by Jedaiah, who was fathered by Shimri, who was fathered by Shemaiah)—
4.38: these people, enumerated by name, were leaders in their respective families, and their clans grew to be very abundant.
4.39: They journeyed as far as the entrance of Gedor on the east side of the valley in order to find pasture for their flocks.
4.40: They discovered abundant and excellent grazing lands there, where the land was very broad, secure, and tranquil, because the former inhabitants there were descendants of Ham.
4.41: Later on, during the reign of King Hezekiah of Judah, these people, enumerated by name, came and attacked both their homes and the Meunim who had settled there and who remain exterminated to this day. They settled down there, taking their place, because there was pasture there for their flocks.
4.42: Some of them—that is, 500 Simeonite men—went to Mount Seir. Under the leadership of Ishi's sons Pelatiah, Neariah, Rephaiah, and Uzziel,
4.43: they destroyed the survivors of the Amalekites who had escaped, and they have lived there to this day.

5.1: Here is a record of the descendants of Reuben, Israel's firstborn. (He was the firstborn, but because he defiled his father's marriage bed, his birthright was transferred to the descendants of Israel's son Joseph. As a result, Reuben is not enrolled in the genealogy according to the birthright.
5.2: Even though Judah became prominent among his relatives—that is, the Commander-in-chief will be his descendant—nevertheless the right of the firstborn went to Joseph.)
5.3: The descendants of Reuben, Israel's firstborn, included Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.
5.4: Joel's descendants were his son Shemaiah, his son Gog, his son Shimei,
5.5: his son Micah, his son Reaiah, his son Baal,
5.6: and his son Beerah, whom King Tiglath-pileser of Assyria carried away into exile, and who was a governor of the descendants of Reuben.
5.7: His relatives, listed by families when the genealogy was enrolled according to their generations, included the chief, Jeiel, Zechariah,
5.8: and Azaz's son Bela, grandson of Shema, and great-grandson of Joel, who lived in Aroer, near Nebo and Baal-meon.
5.9: He also lived eastward as far as the entrance to the wilderness this side of the Euphrates River, because their cattle had increased in the territory of Gilead.
5.10: During the reign of Saul they declared war on the Hagrites, who fell in battle by their hand. They lived in their tents throughout all of east Gilead.
5.11: Gad's descendants lived beside them in the land of Bashan as far as Salecah:
5.12: They included Joel their chief, Shapham their second in command, Janai, and Shaphat, who lived in Bashan.
5.13: Their seven relatives, according to the households of their clans, included Michael, Meshullam, Sheba, Jorai, Jacan, Zia, and Eber.
5.14: These were the descendants of Huri's son Abihail, who was fathered by Jaroah, who was fathered by Gilead, who was fathered by Michael, who was fathered by Jeshishai, who was fathered by Jahdo, and who was fathered by Buz:
5.15: Abdiel's son Ahi, who was the grandson of Guni, was chief in their clan.
5.16: They lived in Gilead, in Bashan and its villages, and in all the surrounding suburbs of Sharon as far as their borders.
5.17: All of them were enrolled by genealogies during the reign of King Jotham of Judah and during the reign of King Jeroboam of Israel.
5.18: The descendants of Reuben, the descendants of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh produced 44,700 valiant soldiers expert in shield, sword, and bow. Trained in warfare, they were equipped to serve at a moment's notice.
5.19: They fought in battle against the Hagrites, Jetur, Naphish, and Nodab.
5.20: When they received assistance against them, the Hagrites and all of their allies were handed over to their control, because they cried out to God during the battle. He honored their entreaty, because they had placed their trust in him.
5.21: They captured 50,000 camels, 250,000 sheep, 2,000 donkeys, and 100,000 war captives from their possessions.
5.22: Many fell slain, because the battle's outcome was directed by God. They lived in their territory until the exile.
5.23: The half-tribe of Manasseh lived in the land, spread out from Bashan to Baal-hermon, including Senir and Mount Hermon.
5.24: These were the leaders of their clans: Epher, Ishi, Eliel, Azriel, Jeremiah, Hodaviah, and Jahdiel—they were mighty warriors, well known men, and leaders of their clans.
5.25: But they were unfaithful to the God of their ancestors by prostituting themselves to the gods of the peoples of the land, whom God had exterminated right in front of them.
5.26: So the God of Israel incited King Pul of Assyria (also known as King Tiglath-pileser of Assyria), who took them prisoner and brought the descendants of Reuben, the descendants of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh to Halah, Habor, Hara, and to the Gozan River, where they remain to this day.

6.1: Levi's descendants included Gershom, Kohath, and Merari.
6.2: Kohath's sons included Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
6.3: Amram's descendants included Aaron, Moses, and Miriam. Aaron's sons included Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
6.4: Eleazar fathered Phinehas, Phinehas fathered Abishua,
6.5: Abishua fathered Bukki, Bukki fathered Uzzi,
6.6: Uzzi fathered Zerahiah, Zerahiah fathered Meraioth,
6.7: Meraioth fathered Amariah, Amariah fathered Ahitub,
6.8: Ahitub fathered Zadok, Zadok fathered Ahimaaz,
6.9: Ahimaaz fathered Azariah, Azariah fathered Johanan,
6.10: and Johanan fathered Azariah, who served as priest in the Temple that Solomon built in Jerusalem.
6.11: Azariah fathered Amariah, Amariah fathered Ahitub,
6.12: Ahitub fathered Zadok, Zadok fathered Shallum,
6.13: Shallum fathered Hilkiah, Hilkiah fathered Azariah,
6.14: Azariah fathered Seraiah, and Seraiah fathered Jehozadak.
6.15: The LORD sent Jehozadak, Judah, and Jerusalem into exile, using Nebuchadnezzar to do it.
6.16: Levi's descendants included Gershom, Kohath, and Merari.
6.17: These are the names of Gershom's descendants: Libni and Shimei.
6.18: Kohath's sons included Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
6.19: Merari's sons included Mahli and Mushi. These are the clans of the descendants of Levi according to their ancestry:
6.20: Gershom's clan included his son Libni, his son Jahath, his son Zimmah,
6.21: his son Joah, his son Iddo, his son Zerah, and his son Jeatherai.
6.22: Kohath's descendants included Amminadab, his son Korah, his son Assir,
6.23: his son Elkanah, his son Ebiasaph, his son Assir,
6.24: his son Tahath, his son Uriel, his son Uzziah, and his son Shaul.
6.25: Elkanah's descendants included Amasai and Ahimoth,
6.26: his son Elkanah, his son Zophai, his son Nahath,
6.27: his son Eliab, his son Jeroham, and his son Elkanah.
6.28: Samuel's descendants included Joel his firstborn and his second son Abijah.
6.29: Merari's descendants included Mahli, his son Libni, his son Shimei, his son Uzzah,
6.30: his son Shimea, his son Haggiah, and his son Asaiah.
6.31: These are the men to whom David handed responsibility for music in the Temple of the LORD, after the ark came to rest there.
6.32: They ministered in song in front of the Tent of Meeting, until Solomon had built the Temple of the LORD in Jerusalem. They served in accordance with orders of service designated for them.
6.33: These are the men who served, including their descendants: From the descendants of Kohath, there was Heman the singer, who had been fathered by Joel, who had been fathered by Samuel,
6.34: who had been fathered by Elkanah, who had been fathered by Jeroham, who had been fathered by Eliel, who had been fathered by Toah,
6.35: who had been fathered by Zuph, who had been fathered by Elkanah, who had been fathered by Mahath, who had been fathered by Amasai,
6.36: who had been fathered by Elkanah, who had been fathered by Joel, who had been fathered by Azariah, who had been fathered by Zephaniah,
6.37: who had been fathered by Tahath, who had been fathered by Assir, who had been fathered by Ebiasaph, who had been fathered by Korah,
6.38: who had been fathered by Izhar, who had been fathered by Kohath, who had been fathered by Levi, who had been fathered by Israel.
6.39: There was also his brother Asaph, who stood to Heman's right. Asaph had been fathered by Berechiah, who had been fathered by Shimea,
6.40: who had been fathered by Michael, who had been fathered by Baaseiah, who had been fathered by Malchijah,
6.41: who had been fathered by Ethni, who had been fathered by Zerah, who had been fathered by Adaiah,
6.42: who had been fathered by Ethan, who had been fathered by Zimmah, who had been fathered by Shimei,
6.43: who had been fathered by Jahath, who had been fathered by Gershom, and who had been fathered by Levi.
6.44: To Heman's left were their relatives who were Merari's sons: Ethan, who had been fathered by Kishi, who had been fathered by Abdi, who had been fathered by Malluch,
6.45: who had been fathered by Hashabiah, who had been fathered by Amaziah, who had been fathered by Hilkiah,
6.46: who had been fathered by Amzi, who had been fathered by Bani, who had been fathered by Shemer,
6.47: who had been fathered by Mahli, who had been fathered by Mushi, who had been fathered by Merari, who had been fathered by Levi,
6.48: along with their relatives, descendants of Levi who had been appointed for all the service of the tent of the Temple of God.
6.49: Meanwhile, Aaron and his sons presented offerings on the altar of burnt offering and on the altar of incense, carrying out the work of the Most Holy Place, making atonement for Israel in accordance with everything that Moses the servant of God had commanded.
6.50: These are Aaron's sons: his son Eleazar, his son Phinehas, his son Abishua,
6.51: his son Bukki, his son Uzzi, his son Zerahiah,
6.52: his son Meraioth, his son Amariah, his son Ahitub,
6.53: his son Zadok, and his son Ahimaaz.
6.54: These are the settlement locations allotted within their borders to Aaron's descendants in the Kohathite clan since the lot was cast in their favor first.
6.55: Hebron in the territory of Judah was allotted to them, along with its surrounding suburbs.
6.56: The fields adjacent to the city and its villages were allotted to Jephunneh's son Caleb.
6.57: They allotted these cities of refuge to the descendants of Aaron: Hebron, Libnah with its surrounding suburbs, Jattir, Eshtemoa with its surrounding suburbs,
6.58: Hilen with its surrounding suburbs, Debir with its surrounding suburbs,
6.59: Ashan with its surrounding suburbs, and Beth-shemesh with its surrounding suburbs.
6.60: From the tribe of Benjamin were allotted Geba with its surrounding suburbs, Alemeth with its surrounding suburbs, and Anathoth with its surrounding suburbs. All their towns allotted to their families totaled thirteen.
6.61: Ten towns were allocated to the rest of the descendants of Kohath by lot out of the family of the tribe, that is, the half-tribe of Manasseh.
6.62: To the descendants of Gershom according to their families were allotted 13 towns in Bashan from the tribes of Issachar, Asher, Naphtali, and Manasseh.
6.63: The descendants of Merari were allotted 12 towns according to their families from the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and Zebulun.
6.64: So the people of Israel gave the descendants of Levi the towns with their surrounding suburbs,
6.65: allocating these towns from the tribes of Judah, Simeon, and Benjamin.
6.66: A few of the families of Kohath's descendants had towns of their territory allotted from the tribe of Ephraim.
6.67: They were given these cities of refuge: Shechem with its surrounding suburbs in the hill country of Ephraim, Gezer with its surrounding suburbs,
6.68: Jokmeam with its surrounding suburbs, Beth-horon with its surrounding suburbs,
6.69: Aijalon with its surrounding suburbs, Gath-rimmon with its surrounding suburbs,
