19.17: My wife says my breath stinks; even my children say I smell bad!
19.18: Even little children hate me; when I get up, they mock me.
19.19: My closest friends detest me; even the ones I love have turned against me.
19.20: I'm a pile of skin and bones; I have barely escaped by the skin of my teeth."
19.21: "Be gracious to me, be gracious to me, my friends, because God's hand has struck me.
19.22: Why are you chasing me, as God has been doing? Aren't you satisfied that I'm sick?
19.23: If only my words were written down; if only they were inscribed in a book
19.24: using an iron stylus with lead for ink! Then they'd be engraved in rock forever.
19.25: "As for me, I know that my Vindicator is alive; And he, the Last One, will take his stand on the soil.
19.26: Even after my skin has been destroyed, clothed in my flesh I will see God,
19.27: whom I will see for myself. My own eyes will look at him— there won't be anyone else for me!— He is the culmination of my innermost desire."
19.28: "When you're thinking about asking yourselves, 'How will we pursue him, since the root of the problem is with him?'
19.29: Make sure that you remain wary of God's sword, for God's wrath brings with it the sword of punishment, by which you'll know there's a judgment."

20.2: "Therefore my anxious thoughts cause me to answer because I'm agitated within me.
20.3: Whenever I hear an insulting rebuke, I respond from my spirit because I understand."
20.4: "Haven't you known this from ancient times, since mankind was placed on the earth?
20.5: The wicked triumph only briefly; the joy of the godless is momentary.
20.6: Though he grow as tall as the sky, or though his head touches the clouds,
20.7: he'll perish forever, like his own excrement; those who saw him will ask, 'Where is he?'
20.8: He'll vanish like a dream, and no one will find him; he will be chased away like a night vision."
20.9: "An eye that gazes at him won't do so again; and his place won't even recognize him.
20.10: His sons will make amends to the poor; their hands will return his wealth.
20.11: Though his bones were full of youthful vigor; yet they will lie down with him in the dust.
20.12: Though evil tastes sweet in his mouth, though he conceals it under his tongue,
20.13: though he savors it and delays swallowing it so he can taste it again and again in his mouth,
20.14: his food will turn rancid in his stomach— it will become a cobra's poison inside him.
20.15: "Though he swallows wealth, he will vomit it; God will dislodge it from his stomach.
20.16: He will suck the poison of cobras; the fangs of a viper will slay him.
20.17: He won't look at the rivers— the torrents of honey and curd.
20.18: "He will restore what he has attained from his work and won't consume it; he won't enjoy the profits from his business transactions,
20.19: because he has crushed and abandoned the poor; he has seized a house that he didn't build.
20.20: "Since his appetite won't quit; he won't let anything escape his lust.
20.21: Because nothing was left for him to devour, therefore his prosperity won't last.
20.22: Even though he is satiated and self-sufficient, he suffers— everyone in any sort of trouble will attack him.
20.23: "It will come about that, when he has filled himself to the full, God will vent his burning anger on him; he will pour it out on him and on his body.
20.24: Though he dodges an iron weapon, a bronze arrow will pierce him.
20.25: It will impale him and come out through his back; the point will glisten as it protrudes through his gall bladder, and he will be terrified.
20.26: "Total darkness has been reserved for his treasures; a fire that has no need to be kindled will devour him and consume whatever remains in his possession.
20.27: Heaven will reveal his iniquity, while the earth will rise up against him.
20.28: A flood will wash away his house; dragging it away when God becomes angry.
20.29: This is what the wicked person inherits from God; it is the inheritance that God appoints for him."

21.2: "Listen carefully to my words; let this encourage all of you.
21.3: Bear with me and let me speak! Then, after I've spoken, you'll be free to mock me.
21.4: After all, isn't my complaint against a human being? If so, why shouldn't I be impatient?
21.5: Look at me, be appalled, and then shut up!
21.6: When I think about this, I'm petrified with terror and my body shudders uncontrollably."
21.7: "Why do the wicked live to reach old age and increase in power and wealth, too?
21.8: Their children grow up while they're alive, and they live to see their grandchildren.
21.9: Their houses are safe from fear, and God's chastisement never visits them.
21.10: Their bull breeds without fail, and their cows calve without miscarriages.
21.11: They release their children to play like sheep; their young ones dance about,
21.12: singing with tambourines and lyres as they rejoice to the sound of flutes.
21.13: They grow old in prosperity, as they descend peacefully into the afterlife.
21.14: "They say to God, 'Turn away from us! We have no desire to know your ways.
21.15: Who is the Almighty, that we should serve him? Where's the profit in talking to him?'
21.16: Behold! Their prosperity isn't in their control! The counsel of the wicked will remain far from me."
21.17: "How often do the wicked have their lights put out? Does calamity ever fall on them? Will God in his anger ever apportion their destruction?
21.18: May they become like a straw, blown away before the wind; like a chaff that's swept off by a storm.
21.19: God stores up their iniquity to repay their children; making them repay so that they may be aware.
21.20: Their own eyes will see their destruction; and they'll drink the wrath of the Almighty.
21.21: What will they care for their household after them, when the number of his months comes to an end?"
21.22: "Can God learn anything? After all, he will judge even the exalted ones.
21.23: Such persons will die in their full vigor, completely prosperous and secure.
21.24: His buckets are filled with milk, his bone marrow is healthy.
21.25: Others die with a bitter soul, never having tasted the good life.
21.26: They both lie down in the dust; and worms cover them."
21.27: "Look! I know your thoughts, your plans are going to harm me.
21.28: You ask, 'Where is the noble person's house?' and 'Where are the tents where the wicked live?'
21.29: Haven't you asked travelers on the highway? Don't you accept their word
21.30: that the wicked person is spared from times of calamity, that he is rescued on the day of wrath?
21.31: Who will expose his conduct to his face? Who will repay him for what he has done
21.32: when he is carried away to the cemetery and guardians are placed to watch his tomb?
21.33: The runoff from the streams will seem sweet to him; everyone will follow after him; countless crows march ahead of him.
21.34: How then, can you console me so worthlessly? What is left of your answers is treachery."

22.1: Then in response, Eliphaz from Teman said:
22.2: "Can a human being be useful to God, since he, who is wise, is sufficient to himself?
22.3: Will it please the Almighty if you are innocent, or does he profit if your life is blameless?
22.4: Will he acquit you just because you fear him, and render a verdict on your behalf?
22.5: Your wickedness is great, isn't it? There's no limit to your iniquity, is there?
22.6: "After all, you've taken collateral from your relatives for no reason; you stripped the naked of their clothing.
22.7: You've neglected to give water to the weary, and you've withheld food from the hungry.
22.8: The land belongs to the powerful, and the privileged thrive in it.
22.9: You sent away widows empty-handed, and broke the outstretched arms of orphans.
22.10: That's why disaster surrounds you, terror suddenly overwhelms you,
22.11: you see nothing but darkness, and a flood of troubles drowns you."
22.12: "Isn't God in heaven above? Consider how far away the stars are, and how lofty they are!
22.13: You've asked, 'What does God know? Can he sort through pitch black darkness?'
22.14: Thick clouds cover him so he can't see as he walks back and forth at heaven's horizon.
22.15: "Will you keep walking on the traditional path that sinners have tread,
22.16: who were snatched away before their time; when their foundation was swept away by a river?
22.17: They told God, 'Get away from us!' and 'What will the Almighty do to them?'
22.18: "Though God fills their houses with good things, the counsel of the wicked will remain far from me.
22.19: The righteous will see this and rejoice; the innocent will insult him, saying,
22.20: Our enemies are sure to be destroyed, and fire will burn up what's left of their riches."
22.21: "Get to know God, and you'll be at peace with him, and then prosperity will come to you.
22.22: Accept what he has to teach you, and treasure his words in your heart.
22.23: "If you return to the Almighty you'll be restored, as you remove iniquity from your household.
22.24: Bury your gold nuggets in the dust, and your source of gold among the stones in a streambed,
22.25: and then the Almighty will be your gold and your refined silver.
22.26: "Then you'll take delight in the Almighty; and will turn your face toward God.
22.27: You'll entreat him and he'll listen to you as you fulfill your vows.
22.28: When you make a decision on something, it will be established for you, and light will brighten your way.
22.29: "For when they're humbled, you may respond; 'It's their pride!' but he delivers the humble.
22.30: He'll even deliver the guilty, who will be delivered through your innocence."

23.2: "I'm still complaining bitterly today; my hand is heavy because of groaning.
23.3: If only I knew where to find him, I would visit him where he has taken his seat.
23.4: I would lay out my case before him; and fill my mouth with arguments.
23.5: I know how he would answer me; I understand what he'll tell me.
23.6: "Would he use his great power to fight me? No, he'll pay attention to me.
23.7: In that place, the upright can reason with him; and I'll be acquitted once and for all by my judge."
23.8: "Look! If I go east, he isn't there! If I go to the west, I don't perceive him.
23.9: If he's working in the north, I can't observe him; If he turns south, I can't see him.
23.10: Because he knows the road on which I travel, when he had tested me, I'll come out like gold.
23.11: My feet stay where his footsteps lead; I kept on his pathway and haven't turned aside.
23.12: I haven't wandered away from the commands that he has spoken; I've treasured what he has said more than my own meals."
23.13: "But he is One—who can change him? He does whatever he wants to do.
23.14: He'll complete what he has planned for me; he has many things in mind for me!
23.15: That's why I'm terrified at his presence! When I think about it, I'm afraid of him.
23.16: God has caused me to faint; the Almighty makes me terrified!
23.17: Nevertheless, I haven't been silenced because of the darkness, even when thick darkness obscures my vision."

24.1: Why doesn't the Almighty reserve time for judgment? and why don't those who know him perceive his days?
24.2: They move boundary stones, steal flocks, and pasture them.
24.3: They drive away the orphan's donkey; they take the ox of the widow as security for a loan;
24.4: They push the needy off the road, and force the poor of the land into hiding.
24.5: "Look! Like wild donkeys in the wilderness, they work diligently as they seek wild game in the desert, food for them and their young ones.
24.6: They reap fodder in the field and glean in the vineyard of the wicked.
24.7: They spend the night naked, without clothing, with no covering against the cold.
24.8: They are wet from mountain rains; without shelter, they cling to a rock.
24.9: "The fatherless are torn from the breast; the poor are taken away as security for a loan.
24.10: They wander around naked, without clothes; hungry, though they carry sheaves of grain.
24.11: They press oil between the olive groves owned by the wicked; they suffer from thirst, even while treading the winepress.
24.12: From the city, dying men groan aloud, and the wounded cries out for help, but God charges no one with wrong.
24.13: "Then there are those who rebel against the light; they are not acquainted with its ways; and they don't stay on its course.
24.14: The murderer rises at dawn to kill the poor and needy; at night, he is like a thief.
24.15: The adulterer watches for twilight, saying, 'No eye is watching me' while he veils his face.
24.16: They break into houses in the dark; during the day they remained sealed in. They don't know daylight.
24.17: As a group, deep darkness is their morning time; fear that lives in darkness is their friend."
24.18: "They remain only a short time on the water's surface; their inheritance will be cursed in the land; no one will work in their vineyards.
24.19: As drought and heat evaporate melting snow, that's what Sheol does with sinners.
24.20: The womb will forget them. Maggots will find them to be a delicacy! They won't be remembered anymore, their iniquity will be cut to pieces like firewood.
24.21: "They prey on the barren woman, and do no favors for widows.
24.22: God prolongs the life of the strong by his power, but they get up in the morning without purpose in life.
24.23: He gives them security and financial support, but he watches everything they do.
24.24: They're exalted momentarily, but then they are gone; they are humbled, just like all the others. They are cut down like heads of corn.
24.25: If this weren't so, who can prove that I'm a liar by showing that there's nothing to what I'm saying?"

25.1: Bildad from Shuah responded and said:
25.2: "Dominion and fear belong to God; who fashions peace in his high heaven.
25.3: Is there any limit to his armies? On whom does his light not shine?
25.4: How can a human being become right with God? How can a human being be pure?
25.5: Behold, even the moon isn't bright, and the stars aren't pure in his eyes.
25.6: How much less is man, who is only a maggot, or a man's children, who are only worms!"

26.2: "What a help you are to the weak! How powerfully you deliver those without strength!
26.3: What counsel you provide to the fool! What insight you provide so abundantly!
26.4: Who helped you say all of this? Who inspired you?"
26.5: "The ghosts of the dead writhe under the waters along with those who live there with them.
26.6: Sheol is naked before God and Abaddon has no clothes.
26.7: He spreads out the north over empty space, suspending the earth over nothing.
26.8: "He restricts the waters within clouds and the clouds don't burst open under them.
26.9: He has enclosed the face of the full moon and spread his clouds over it.
26.10: He has delimited a boundary over the surface of the oceans as a limit between light and darkness.
26.11: The pillars of the heavens tremble and are astounded at his rebuke.
26.12: By his power he disturbs the sea; and with his skill he shatters the sea monster.
26.13: he clears the skies with his wind; his hands have pierced the fleeing serpent.
26.14: Indeed, these are the fringes of his ways, and how faint is the whisper we've heard of it! But who can comprehend the thunder of his might?"

27.1: Job continued with his discussion and said:
27.2: "The living God has withheld justice from me; the Almighty has made my life bitter.
27.3: As long as I can breathe; as long as God's breath is in my nostrils,
27.4: I won't speak lies nor will I utter deceit.
27.5: Far be it from me to admit that you're right! I intend to maintain my integrity even if it kills me!
27.6: I'll retain my righteousness and not compromise it; my conscience won't rebuke me at any time.
27.7: "May my enemy be like the wicked; my adversary like the unjust.
27.8: For where is the hope of the godless when he is eliminated; when God takes away his life?
27.9: Will God hear his cry when distress overtakes him?
27.10: Will he take delight in the Almighty? Will he call on God at all times?"
27.11: "I'll teach you about the power of God, that which is with the Almighty I won't conceal.
27.12: Look! All of you have been watching, so why have you become so completely worthless?
27.13: "This is what a wicked person inherits from God, and what the ruthless will receive from the Almighty:
27.14: If he has many children, their destiny is to die by the sword, and his descendants won't have enough food.
27.15: Those who do survive him disease will bury, and his widow won't even weep.
27.16: "Though he hoards silver like dust, and stores away garments like clay,
27.17: whatever he stores up, the righteous will wear, and the innocent will inherit that silver!
27.18: "He has built his house like a moth's cocoon, like a temporary sunshade that a watchman makes.
27.19: He will go to bed wealthy, but won't be doing that anymore! When he opens his eyes, it will be gone!
27.20: Terror will overtake him like a flood, at night, a tornado will sweep him away.
27.21: He'll be swept up by a storm wind and carried away; he'll be whirled away from his place.
27.22: It will toss him around without pity. He'll try to break free from its grip,
27.23: but it will clap its hands over him, hissing at him as it lunges toward him."

28.1: "Surely there are mines for silver and places where gold is refined.
28.2: Iron is taken from the ground; and copper is smelted from ore.
28.3: Mankind limits the darkness as they search the deepest depths for ore in unfathomable darkness.
28.4: He sinks his shaft far from human habitations, in a place forgotten by explorers; they hang on harnesses as they swing back and forth.
28.5: "While the ground produces food, underneath it is torn up and burning hot,
28.6: where stones are sapphire and gold dust can be found,
28.7: a place where birds of prey never fly, and the eyes of the falcon have never seen.
28.8: The proud beasts haven't walked there; lions have never passed over it.
28.9: "Using a flint, he thrusts his hand, overturning mountains by the roots.
28.10: He cuts a channel through the rocks, while his eyes search for anything of value.
28.11: He dams up flowing rivers, bringing hidden things to light."
28.12: "Where can wisdom be found? Where is understanding's home?
28.13: Mankind doesn't appreciate their value; and you won't find it anywhere on earth.
28.14: The deepest ocean says, 'It's not within me.' and the sea says, 'You'll never find it with me.'
28.15: You can't buy it with gold, and its value cannot be calculated in silver.
28.16: It cannot be compared to gold from Ophir, with precious onyx, or with sapphire.
28.17: It cannot be compared to gold and fine glass crystal, nor can it be exchanged for gold-plated weaponry.
28.18: Don't even bother to mention coral and crystal— wisdom is more valuable than a bag of rubies.
28.19: It can neither be compared with the topaz of Ethiopia nor valued in comparison to pure gold."
28.20: "From where, then, does wisdom originate? Where does understanding live?
28.21: It has been concealed from the sight of every living creature and hidden even from the birds in the skies.
28.22: Abaddon and death said, 'We did hear a rumor about it.'
28.23: God understands how to get there; he knows where they live.
28.24: For he looks as far as the ends of the earth and sees everything under the sky.
28.25: "He imparted weight to the wind; he regulated water by his measurement.
28.26: He set in place ordinances for the rain; and determined the pathway for thunder that accompanies lightning.
28.27: Then he looked at wisdom, and fixed it in place; he established it, and also examined it.
28.28: He has commanded mankind: 'To fear the Lord—that is wisdom; to move away from evil—that is understanding.'"

29.1: Then Job continued with his discourse:
29.2: "I wish I could go back to how things were a few months ago; when God used to watch over me,
29.3: when his lamp used to shine over my head, so I could walk through the dark,
29.4: like when I was in my prime and God trusted me with his secrets!
29.5: "The Almighty was still with me back then, and my children were still around me.
29.6: I was successful wherever I went, and even the rocks poured out streams of olive oil for me."
29.7: "Whenever I went out to the city gate, a seat had been reserved for me in the plaza.
29.8: The young men would see me and withdraw, and the aged would rise and stand.
29.9: Nobles would refrain from speaking, covering their mouths with their hands.
29.10: The voices of the commanders-in-chief were hushed, and their tongues would cling to the roofs of their mouths."
29.11: "When people heard me speak, they blessed me; when people saw me, they approved me,
29.12: because I delivered the poor who were crying for help, along with orphans who had no one to help them.
29.13: Those who were about to die blessed me, and I made widows sing for joy.
29.14: I put on righteousness like clothing; my just decisions were like a robe and a turban.
29.15: I served as eyes for the blind and feet for the lame.
29.16: I was a father to the needy; I diligently inquired into the case of those I didn't know.
29.17: I broke the fangs of the wicked, and made him drop the prey."
29.18: "I used to say: 'I will die in my home. I'm going to live as many days as there are grains of sand on the shore.
29.19: My roots have spread out and have found water, and dew settles at night on my branches.
29.20: My glory renews for me and my bow is as good as new in my hand.'
29.21: "They listened and waited for me, as they remained in silence for my counsel.
29.22: After I spoke, they had nothing to say, when what I said hit them.
29.23: They waited for me as one waits for rain, as one opens his mouth to drink in a spring rain shower.
29.24: I smiled at them when they had no confidence, and no one could discourage me.
29.25: I set an example of the way to live, as a leader would; I lived like a king among his army; like one who comforts mourners."

30.1: "But now they mock me; men who are far younger than I, whose fathers I would have hated to entrust with my own sheep dogs.
30.2: Furthermore, what could I have gained from men whose strength is gone?
30.3: Unproductive due to poverty and hunger, they could only scratch in parched soil, devastated and desolated.
30.4: "They would pluck off herbs from salt marshes to eat; and roots of the broom shrub for food.
30.5: Driven away from human company, they were shouted at as though they were thieves.
30.6: They lived in the most dangerous of ravines, in holes in the ground, and among rocks.
30.7: They bray like donkeys among the bushes and huddle together under the desert weeds.
30.8: Sons of fools and of uncertain reputation, they have been driven from the land by scourging."
30.9: "Now, I've become the object of their mocking melodies; I'm nothing but a fool's proverb to them!
30.10: They abhor me—they keep their distance from me; but they don't refrain from spitting at the sight of me.
30.11: But God has loosened his cord and afflicted me; so they've cast off all restraints in my presence.
30.12: "A wretched crowd ambushes me to my right; they trip my feet; they build up their path of calamity for me.
30.13: They tear up my pathways; they profit from my destruction, and they need no help to do this!
30.14: They come like those who breach through a wall; as everything crashes around me they'll roll on and on!
30.15: My greatest fears have overcome me; my honor is assaulted as though by a wind storm; my prosperity evaporates like a morning cloud."
30.16: "Now, my soul pours itself out; the time of my affliction has taken control of me.
30.17: The night racks my bones; and the pain that gnaws on me will not rest.
30.18: My clothes are disheveled by his forceful treatment of me; he restricts my movement like the collar of my cloak.
30.19: "He tossed me into the mire; I've become like dust and ashes.
30.20: I cry for help to you, but you won't answer me; I stand still, but you only look at me.
30.21: You changed toward me, and now you're cruel to me; with your mighty hand you are persecuting me;
30.22: you carried me off in a wind storm, making me ride on it while you toss me about as the storm roars around me.
30.23: I know that you're about to kill me, so I'm about to go to the house that's appointed for all the living."
30.24: "Surely he won't stretch his hand against the needy, will he, especially if they cry to him in their calamity?
30.25: Haven't I wept for the one who is going through hard times? Haven't I grieved for the needy?
30.26: I have hoped for good, but evil came instead; I have hoped for light, but darkness came.
30.27: I'm boiling mad inside, and I won't remain silent; the time for my affliction to confront me has arrived.
30.28: "In growing darkness, I walked without sunlight; I stood in the congregation to cry for help.
30.29: I've become a brother to jackals, and a friend to ostriches.
30.30: My skin turns black all over me; and my bones seem burned from the heat.
30.31: But my harp is in mourning; my flute plays only songs for those who are weeping." Job Asserts His Moral Innocence

31.1: "I made a covenant with my eyes; how, then, can I focus my attention on a virgin?
31.2: What would I have from God above, what heritage from the Almighty on high,
31.3: if not calamity that is due the unjust, and misfortune that is due those who practice iniquity?
31.4: He watches my life, observing every one of my actions, does he not?"
31.5: "If I've lived my life in the company of vanity, or run quickly to embrace deception,
31.6: let my righteousness be weighed in honest scales, and God will make known my integrity.
31.7: If I have stepped away from the way, or if my heart covets whatever my eyes see, or if some other blemish clings to my hands,
31.8: what I've planted, let another eat or let my crops be uprooted."
31.9: "If my heart has been seduced by a woman and I've laid in wait at my friend's door,
31.10: then let my wife cook for another person and may someone else sleep with her,
31.11: because something as lascivious as that is an iniquity that should be judged.
31.12: The fires of Abaddon will burn, disrupting every part of my eternal reward."
31.13: "If I've refused to help my male and female servants when they complain against me,
31.14: what will I do when God stands up to act? When he asks the questions, how will I answer him?
31.15: The one who made me in the womb made them, too, didn't he? Didn't the same one prepare each of us in the womb?"
31.16: "If I refused to grant the desire of the poor or exhausted the eyes of the widow,
31.17: if I ate my meals by myself without feeding orphans,
31.18: (even a poor man had grown up with me as if I were his father, and even though I had guided the widow from the time I was born),
31.19: if I've observed someone who is about to die for lack of clothes or if I have no clothing to give to the poor,
31.20: if he hadn't thanked me from the bottom of his heart, if he had not been warmed by wool from my sheep,
31.21: if I've raised my hand against an orphan when I thought I would against him in court,
31.22: then let my arm fall from its socket; and may my arm be torn off at the shoulder.
31.23: For I'm terrified of what calamity God may have in store for me; and I cannot endure his grandeur."
31.24: "If I've put my confidence in gold, if I've told gold, 'You're my security,'
31.25: if I've found joy in great wealth that I own, if I've earned a lot with my own hands,
31.26: if I look at the sun when it shines or the moon as it rises in steady splendor,
31.27: so that in the depths of my deceived heart I worshipped them with my mouth and hands,
31.28: this is also a sin that deserves to be judged, since I would have tried to deceive God above."
31.29: "Have I rejoiced in the destruction of those who hate me, or have I been happy that evil caught up with him?
31.30: No, I haven't allowed my mouth to sin by asking for his life with a curse.
31.31: People in my household have said, 'We cannot find anyone who has not been satisfied with his meat,' haven't they?
31.32: No stranger ever spent the night in the street, because I opened my doors to travelers."
31.33: "Have I covered my transgression like other people, to conceal iniquity within myself?
31.34: Have I feared large crowds? Has my family's contempt ever terrified me so that I remained silent and wouldn't go outside?"
31.35: "Who will grant me a hearing? Here's my signature —let the Almighty answer! Since my adversary indicted me,
31.36: I'll wear it on my shoulder, or tie it on my head for a crown!
31.37: I'll give an account for every step I've taken; I'll approach him confidently like a Commander-in-Chief."
31.38: "If my land were to cry out against me or if all its furrows wept as one,
31.39: If I've consumed its produce without paying for it and snuffed out the life of its owners;
31.40: may thorns spring up instead of wheat, and obnoxious weeds instead of barley." With this, Job's discourse with his friends is completed.

32.1: These three men stopped responding to Job, because he was claiming to be righteous, in his own opinion.
32.2: But then Barachel's son Elihu from Buz, one of Ram's descendants, got really angry. He was furious with Job because he had been declaring himself righteous instead of vindicating God.
32.3: Furthermore, he was furious with his three friends because they had not answered Job, but instead had condemned him.
32.4: Elihu waited to have a word with Job, since the others were older than he,
32.5: but when he saw that there had been no response from those three, he got even more angry.
32.6: Barachel's son Elihu from Buz responded and said: I'm younger than you are. Because you're older, I was terrified to tell you what I know.
32.7: I thought, experience should speak; abundance of years teaches wisdom.
32.8: However, a spirit exists in mankind, and the Almighty's breath gives him insight.
32.9: "The aged aren't always wise, nor do the elderly always understand justice.
32.10: Therefore I'm saying, 'Listen to me!' Then I'll declare what I know.
32.11: "Look! I have waited to hear your speech, so I listened to your insights while you searched for the right words to say.
32.12: Indeed, I paid close attention to you all, but none of you were able to refute Job or answer his arguments convincingly.
32.13: "So that you cannot claim, 'We have found wisdom!' let God do the rebuking, not man;
32.14: let him not direct a rebuke toward me. I won't be responding to him with your arguments.
32.15: "Job's friends won't reason with him anymore; discouraged, words escape them.
32.16: Shall I continue to wait, since they're no longer talking? After all, they're only standing there; they're no longer responding.
32.17: "I will contribute my arguments as an answer; I'll declare what I know,
32.18: because I'm filled with things to say, and my spirit within me compels me to speak.
32.19: My insides feel like unvented wine, like it's about to burst like a new wineskin.
32.20: "Let me speak! I need relief! Let me open my lips and respond.
32.21: I won't discriminate against anyone, and I won't flatter any person,
32.22: since I don't know the first thing about how to flatter; and the one who made me would sweep me away as if I were nothing."

33.1: "Now please listen to what I have to say, Job. Listen to every word!
33.2: Look! I've begun to speak, and I'm fashioning my words.
33.3: I speak from the innocence of my heart; and my lips will utter what I sincerely know.
33.4: "The spirit of God fashioned me; and the breath of the Almighty gives me life.
33.5: Answer me, if you can! Present your case! Take your stand in my presence!
33.6: Look! As far as God is concerned, I'm just like you are— I, too, have been pinched off from a piece of clay.
33.7: Don't be afraid of me; I'll go easy on you."
33.8: "You spoke clearly so I could hear; I've heard what you've said:
33.9: I'm pure. I'm without sin; I'm innocent. I'm harboring no iniquity inside of me.
33.10: Nevertheless, God has found a pretext to attack me; he considers me his enemy.
33.11: He has bound my feet in shackles, and keeps watching everything I do.'"
33.12: "You aren't right about this; My response is that God is greater than human beings.
33.13: Why are you arguing with him? He doesn't have to give explanations for what he does to you!
33.14: "God speaks time and time again — but nobody notices—
33.15: in a dream or night vision, when a deep sleep falls on mankind while they sleep on their beds.
33.16: That's when he opens the ear of mankind, authenticating his messages to them,
33.17: turning a person from his actions, keeping him from pride,
33.18: sparing his soul from the Pit and his life from violent death.
33.19: "He is being reproved by painful bed rest, with continual aching in his bones.
33.20: He cannot stand his food, and he has no desire for appetizing food.
33.21: His flesh wastes away; his bones, which once couldn't be seen, are visible.
33.22: His soul is getting close to the Pit; his life is approaching its executioner."
33.23: "If there's a messenger appointed to mediate for Job —one out of a thousand— to represent the man's integrity on his behalf,
33.24: to show favor to him and to plead, 'Deliver him from having to go down to the Pit — I know where his ransom is!'
33.25: Let his flesh be rejuvenated as he was in his youth! Let him recover the strength of his youth.
33.26: Let him pray to God and he will accept him; he will appear before him with joyful shouts!"
33.27: "He'll sing to mankind with these words: 'I've sinned. I have twisted what is right. Yet he has not repaid me like I deserve.
33.28: He has redeemed my soul from going down to the Pit; my life will see the light.'
33.29: Indeed God does all these things again and again with a person
33.30: to bring back his soul from the Pit; to light him with the light of life."
33.31: "Job, pay attention! Listen to me! Be silent and let me speak.
33.32: If you have anything to say, answer me; speak up, because I'd be happy to vindicate you.
33.33: But if you have nothing to say, then at least listen to me! Be quiet and learn some wisdom from me."

34.2: "Listen to what I have to say, you wise men! Pay attention to me, you educated people!
34.3: Since the ear tests words like a palate tastes food,
34.4: let's choose what's right for us. Let's consider among ourselves what is good."
34.5: Now this is Job's claim: 'Even though I'm innocent, God has stopped treating me righteously.
34.6: Have I lied concerning the justice that I deserve? My wound is incurable, though transgression cannot be attributed to me.'
34.7: "What man is like Job, who drinks mockery like water,
34.8: traffics in those who practice evil, and walks with wicked people?
34.9: Because he says, 'There's no profit for a man to find joy with God.'"
34.10: "Therefore you men of understanding, listen to me! Far be it for God to practice wickedness, or the Almighty to do what is wrong,
34.11: because he repays a person for his behavior; and according to a person's conduct, he lets it happen to him.
34.12: Truly, God doesn't practice wickedness, and the Almighty doesn't pervert justice.
34.13: Who entrusted the earth to him? Who made him responsible for the entire inhabited world?
34.14: If he were to decide to do so, that is, to take back to himself his spirit and breath of life,
34.15: every living thing would die all at once, and mankind would return to dust."
34.16: If you have understanding, listen to this! Pay attention to what I have to say:
34.17: Can one who hates justice really govern? And if God is righteous and mighty, can you condemn him?
34.18: Can one say to a king, 'You're vile!' or to nobles, 'You're wicked!'?
34.19: Who isn't partial to princes? Who doesn't give preference to the nobles over the poor? Nevertheless, all of them are his handiwork.
34.20: "They die suddenly, in the middle of the night; people suffer seizures and pass away; even valiant men can be taken away— and not by human hands.
34.21: Yes, Job, his eyes constantly watch the behavior of human beings; he carefully observes their every step.
34.22: There's no such thing as darkness to him— not even deep darkness— that can conceal those who practice evil.
34.23: He won't examine mankind further, that they would go before God to judgment.
34.24: He shatters valiant men without a need to investigate, and he raises others in their place.
34.25: Thus he acknowledges their behavior, and overcomes them; when night time comes, they are crushed.
34.26: "He strikes the wicked among them in a place where they can be seen
34.27: because they've abandoned their pursuit of him and had no respect for any of his ways.
34.28: As a result, the cries of the poor have reached him and he has heard the cry of the afflicted.
34.29: "If he remains silent, who will condemn him? If he conceals his face, who can see him? He watches over both nation and individual alike,
34.30: to keep the godless man from reigning or laying a snare for the people."
34.31: "Has anyone ever really told God, 'I've endured, and I won't act corruptly anymore.
34.32: What I don't see, instruct me! If I've done anything evil, I won't repeat it!'
34.33: "Should you not be paid back, since you have rejected him? You do the choosing! I won't! Tell us what you know!
34.34: "Men of understanding, speak to me! Are any of you men wise? Then listen to me!
34.35: Job has been speaking from his own ignorance, and what he has to say lacks insight!
34.36: Oh, how Job needs to be given a full court trial, as a rebuke to those who practice evil,
34.37: because he has been adding rebellion to his sin; he claps his hands among us, and keeps on ranting against God."

35.2: "Are you saying that it's just for you to claim, 'I'm more righteous than God?'
35.3: After all, you've asked what your benefit will be: 'What will I profit from refraining from sin?'
35.4: I'm going to respond to that statement, and to your friends with you."
35.5: "Observe the heavens! Take a look around! Look! The clouds are higher than you, aren't they?
35.6: If you sin, what will that do to harm him? If you add transgression to transgression what will it do to him?
35.7: If you are righteous, what will you add to him? What can God receive from your efforts?
35.8: Your wickedness affects only yourself; and your righteousness, only human beings.
35.9: "They cry out because they have many oppressors; they cry for help because the powerful are abusing them.
35.10: He never asks, 'Where is God, my Creator, who gives me songs in the night,
35.11: who teaches us more than the earth's wild animals, and makes us wiser than the birds of the sky?'
35.12: "They cry out there, but he doesn't answer because of the arrogance of those who practice evil.
35.13: Theirs is a useless plea— God won't listen; the Almighty won't pay any attention.
35.14: Even though you complain that you can't perceive him, your case is already pending for judgment in his presence so keep on placing your hope in him.
35.15: "So now, if he doesn't inflict punishment in his anger, then he doesn't keep track of your many transgressions.
35.16: When he began speaking, he communicated only worthlessness; he added words upon words without knowing anything."

36.2: "Be patient with me a moment longer, and I'll show you that there's more to say on God's behalf.
36.3: I'll take what I know to its logical conclusion and ascribe righteousness to my Creator,
36.4: because what I have to say isn't deceptive, and the one who has perfect knowledge is with you."
36.5: "Indeed God is mighty and he doesn't show disrespect; he is mighty and strong of heart.
36.6: He doesn't let the wicked live; he grants justice to the afflicted.
36.7: He won't stop looking at righteous people; he seats them on thrones with kings forever, and they are exalted.
36.8: "If they're bound in chains, caught in ropes of affliction,
36.9: he'll reveal their actions to them, when their transgressions have become excessive.
36.10: He opens their ears and instructs them, commanding them to repent from evil.
36.11: If they listen and serve him, they'll finish their lives in prosperity and their years will be pleasant.
36.12: "But if they won't listen, they'll perish by the sword and die in their ignorance.
36.13: The godless at heart cherish anger; they won't cry out for help when God afflicts them.
36.14: They die in their youth; and their life will end among temple prostitutes.
36.15: He'll deliver the afflicted through their afflictions and open their ears when they are oppressed."
36.16: "Indeed, he drew you away from the brink of distress to a spacious place without constraints, filling your festive table with bountiful food.
36.17: But now you are occupied with the case of the wicked; but justice and judgment will be served.
36.18: So that no one entices you with riches, don't let a large ransom turn you astray.
36.19: "Will your wealth sustain you when you're in distress, despite your most powerful efforts?
36.20: Don't long for night, when people vanish in their place.
36.21: Be careful! Don't turn to evil, because of this you will be tried by more than affliction.
36.22: "Indeed, God is exalted in his power. Who is like him as a teacher?
36.23: Who ordained his path for him, and who has asked him, 'You are wrong, aren't you?'
36.24: Remember to magnify his awesome activities, about which mortal man has sung.
36.25: All of mankind sees him; human beings observe him from afar off."
36.26: "God is truly awesome, beyond what we know; the number of his years is unknowable.
36.27: He draws up drops of water, distilling it to rain and mist.
36.28: When the clouds pour down; they drop their rain on all of humanity.
36.29: "Furthermore, can anyone understand cloud patterns, or the thundering in his pavilion?
36.30: He scatters his lightning above it, and covers the bottom of the sea.
36.31: He uses them to judge some people and give food to many.
36.32: His hands are covered with lightning that he commands to strike his designated target.
36.33: His thunder declares his presence; and tells the animals what is coming."

37.1: "Now I'll conclude with this: my heart is trembling violently; it feels like it's about to leap from my body!
37.2: Listen carefully to his thundering voice; to the sound that rumbles from his mouth.
37.3: He releases his lightning throughout the sky, to the ends of the earth.
37.4: His thunder roars after it; his majestic voice will thunder; and no one can trace them once his voice has been heard.
37.5: "God thunders with his wondrous voice; he does awesome works that we don't comprehend.
37.6: For he says to the snow, 'Fall to the earth.' He tells the rain, 'Pour down,' then it rains profusely.
37.7: "He puts a limit to the skill of every person; to delineate all people from what they do.
37.8: "Then a beast enters its lair and remains in its den.
37.9: "From the south, a whirlwind proceeds, out of the icy north winds.
37.10: From the breath of God ice is produced, and a wide body of water is frozen.
37.11: He also loads the clouds with moisture, scattering his lightning with the clouds.
37.12: It whirls about in circles at his direction to accomplish all that he commands throughout the surface of the entire world,
37.13: whether for discipline on his land or to demonstrate his gracious love, he causes it to be realized."
37.14: "Pay attention to this, Job! Stand still, and consider the wondrous attributes of God.
37.15: Do you know how God ordains them, and makes his lightning to flash throughout his clouds?
37.16: Do you understand his wondrous work of balancing the clouds, the one whose knowledge is perfect,
37.17: you whose garments are hot, even though the land is cooled by a south wind?
37.18: Can you spread out the skies like he does; can you cast them as one might a mirror?
37.19: Tell us! What are we to say to him? Can we prepare our case to face him when our faces are in darkness?
37.20: Has it been relayed to God that I want to talk? Can a person speak when he is confused?"
37.21: "So then, the sun is too bright to gaze at, is it not? The sky is swept clean by the wind that blows, is it not?
37.22: From the north he brings gold; around God is awesome splendor.
37.23: We cannot find the Almighty— he is majestic in power and justice, and overflowing with righteousness; he never oppresses.
37.24: Therefore humanity fears him, which none of the wise can quite comprehend."

38.1: The LORD responded to Job from the whirlwind and said:
38.2: "Who is this who keeps darkening my counsel without knowing what he's talking about?
38.3: Stand up like a man! I'll ask you some questions, and you give me some answers!"
38.4: "Where were you when I laid the foundation of my earth? Tell me, since you're so informed!
38.5: Who set its measurement? Am I to assume you know? Who stretched a boundary line over it?
38.6: On what were its bases set? Who laid its corner stone
38.7: while the morning stars sang together and all the divine beings shouted joyfully?
38.8: "Who enclosed the sea with limits when it gushed out of the womb,
38.9: when I made clouds to be its clothes and thick darkness its swaddling blanket,
38.10: when I proscribed a boundary for it, set in place bars and doors for it;
38.11: and said, 'You may come only this far and no more. Your majestic waves will stop here.'?
38.12: "Have you ever commanded the morning at any time during your life? Do you know where the dawn lives,
38.13: where it seizes the edge of the earth and shakes the wicked out of it?
38.14: Like clay is molded by a signet ring, the earth's hills and valleys then stand out like the colors of a garment.
38.15: Then from the wicked their light is withheld and their upraised arm is broken.
38.16: "Have you been to the source of the sea and walked about in the recesses of the deepest ocean?
38.17: Have the gates of death been revealed to you? Have you seen the gates of the deepest darkness?
38.18: Do you understand the breadth of the earth? Tell me, since you know it all!
38.19: "Where is the road to where the light lives? Or where does the darkness live?
38.20: Can you take it to its homeland, since you know the path to his house?
38.21: You should know! After all, you had been born back then, so the number of your days is great!
38.22: "Have you entered the storehouses of the snow or seen where the hail is stored,
38.23: which I've reserved for the tribulation to come, for the day of battle and war?
38.24: Where is the lightning diffused or the east wind scattered around the earth?
38.25: "Who cuts canals for storm floods, and paths for the lightning and thunder,
38.26: to bring rain upon a land without inhabitants, a desert in which no human beings live,
38.27: to satisfy a desolate and devastated desert, causing it to sprout vegetation?
38.28: "Does the rain have a father? Who fathered the dew?
38.29: Whose womb brings forth the ice? Who gives birth to frost out of an empty sky,
38.30: when water solidifies like stone and the surface of the deepest sea freezes?
38.31: "Can you bind the chains of Pleiades or loosen the cords of Orion?
38.32: Can you bring out constellations in their season? Can you guide the Bear with her cubs?
38.33: Do you know the laws of the heavens? Can you regulate their authority over the earth?
38.34: "Can you call out to the clouds, so that abundant water drenches you?
38.35: Can you command the lightning, so that it goes forth and calls to you, 'Look at us!'
38.36: "Who sets wisdom within you, or imbues your mind with understanding?
38.37: Who has the wisdom to be able to count the clouds, or to empty the water jars of heaven,
38.38: when dust dries into a mass and then breaks apart into clods?
38.39: "Can you hunt prey for the lioness to satisfy young lions
38.40: when they crouch in their dens and lie in ambush in their lairs?
38.41: Who prepares food for the raven, when its offspring cry out to God as they wander for lack of food?"

39.1: "Do you know when the mountain goat gives birth? Do you watch the doe as it calves its young?
39.2: Can you count the months of their gestation? Do you know the time when they give birth,
39.3: when they crouch down to give birth to their offspring, and let go of their birth pangs?
39.4: Their young are strong; they grow up in the open field; then they go off and don't return to them."
39.5: "Who sets the wild donkey free? Who loosens the bonds of the wild donkey
39.6: to whom I've given the Arabah for a home; the salt plain for his dwelling place?
39.7: He despises city noises; he ignores the shouts of the driver.
39.8: He ranges the mountains that are his pasture to search for anything green.
39.9: Is the wild ox willing to serve you? Will he sleep at night near your feeding trough?
39.10: Can you bind the ox to plow a furrow with a rope? Will he harrow after you in the valley?
39.11: Will you trust him because of his great strength and entrust your labor to him?
39.12: Will you trust him that he'll bring in your grain, and gather it to your threshing floor?"
39.13: "The wings of the ostrich flap joyously, but aren't its pinions and feathers like the stork?
39.14: She abandons her eggs on the ground and lets them be warmed in the sand,
39.15: but she forgets that a foot might crush them or any wild animal might trample them.
39.16: She mistreats her young as though they're not hers, and she has no fear that her labor may be in vain,
39.17: because God didn't grant her wisdom and never gave her understanding.
39.18: And yet when she gets ready to run, she laughs at the horse and its rider."
39.19: Do you instill the horse with strength? Do you clothe its neck with a mane?
39.20: Can you make him leap like the locust, and make the splendor of his snorting terrifying?
39.21: He paws the ground in the valley and rejoices in his strength; he goes out to face weapons.
39.22: He scoffs at fear and is never scared; he never retreats from a sword.
39.23: A quiver of arrows rattles against his side, along with a flashing spear and a lance.
39.24: Leaping in his excitement, he takes in the ground; he cannot stand still when the trumpets sound!
39.25: When the trumpet blasts he'll neigh, 'Aha! Aha!' From a distance he can sense war, the war cry of generals, and their shouting."
39.26: "Is it by your understanding that the hawk flies, spreading its wings toward the south?
39.27: Does the eagle soar high at your command and build its nest on the highest crags?
39.28: He dwells on the crags where he makes his home, there on the rocky crag is his stronghold.
39.29: From there he searches for prey, and his eyes recognize it from a distance.
39.30: His young ones feast on blood; he'll be found wherever there's a carcass."

40.1: The LORD continued his response to Job by saying:
40.2: "Should the one who is fighting the Almighty find fault with him? Let God's accuser answer."
40.3: Then Job replied to the LORD. He said:
40.4: "I must look insignificant to you! How can I answer you? I'm speechless.
40.5: I spoke once, but I can't answer; I tried a second time, but I won't do so anymore."
40.6: The LORD answered Job from the wind storm and told him:
40.7: "Stand up like a man! I'll ask you some questions, and you give me some answers!
40.8: Indeed would you annul my justice and condemn me, just so you can claim that you're righteous?
40.9: Do you have strength like God? Can you create thunder with a sound like he can?"
40.10: "When you have adorned yourself with exalted majesty, clothed yourself with splendor and dignity,
40.11: dispensed the fury of your anger, made sure that you have humbled every proud person,
40.12: stared down and subdued every proud person, trampled the wicked right where they are,
40.13: buried them in the dust together, and sent them bound to that secret place,
40.14: then I will applaud you myself! I'll admit that you can deliver yourself by your own efforts!"
40.15: "Please observe Behemoth, which I made along with you. He eats grass like an ox.
40.16: Now take a look at the strength that he has in his loins, and in the muscles of his abdomen.
40.17: His tail protrudes stiffly, like cedar; the sinews of his thigh interlink for strength.
40.18: His bones are conduits of bronze; his strong bones are like bars of iron.
40.19: He is the grandest of God's undertakings, yet his creator is approaching him with his sword.
40.20: Mountains produce food for him, where all the wild animals frolic.
40.21: He lies under the lotus trees, hiding under reeds and marshes.
40.22: The lotus trees cover him with their shade, and willows that line the wadis surround him.
40.23: What you see as a raging river doesn't alarm him; he is confident when the Jordan overflows.
40.24: Are your eyes looking to capture him, or to pierce his snout with a bridle?"

41.1: "Can you draw Leviathan out of the water with a hook, or tie down his tongue with a rope?
41.2: Can you attach a bridle to his snout, or pierce his jaw with a hook?
41.3: Will he make many supplications to you, or will he beg you for mercy?
41.4: Will he try to make a deal with you, so that you may take him in servitude forever?
41.5: "Will you play with him like a pet bird? Will you put a leash on him for your little girls?
41.6: Will your business be able to buy him, Will you divide him among your merchant friends?
41.7: Will you fill his flesh with harpoons, or his head with lances?
41.8: Lay your hand on him, and you'll remember the struggle. You'll never do that again!
41.9: "Look! Anyone's hope to capture him will prove itself false; anyone would be terrified just by looking at him.
41.10: No one is fierce enough to dare to arouse him. "Who, then, can stand in my presence and face me?
41.11: Who can take me to court and be reconciled to me? All of heaven is mine.
41.12: "I won't be silent concerning his limbs, his mighty strength, and orderly frame.
41.13: Who can strip off his outer armor? Who can approach him with a bridle?
41.14: Who dares to open his mouth, since it is ringed with his terrible teeth!
41.15: His protective scales are his pride, they lie sealed tightly together.
41.16: Each one is so close to the other that not even air comes in between them.
41.17: Each is attached to the other, grasping each other so they cannot be separated.
41.18: "His snorting releases flashes of light; his eyes are like the rays of the dawn.
41.19: Flames blaze from his mouth; streams of sparking fire fly out.
41.20: Smoke billows from his nostrils; like a boiling pot or burning reeds.
41.21: His breath can ignite coal; and flames proceed from his mouth.
41.22: "His neck is so powerful that all who meet him are terrified.
41.23: There is no flaw in his body's armor; it is firmly fixed on him and unbreachable.
41.24: His heart is as strong as stone, it is as hard as a lower millstone.
41.25: When he rears up, the mighty are terrified; they are bewildered as he thrashes about.
41.26: "Thrusting at him with a sword won't be effective, nor will spears, darts, or javelins.
41.27: He regards iron like straw, and hardened bronze like a dead tree.
41.28: Arrows won't make him flee; stones from a sling are only pebbles to him.
41.29: Clubs are like twigs; he laughs at the whoosh of the javelin.
41.30: "Beneath him he is armored as with sharp potsherds; he tears through muddy ground like a threshing sledge through grain.
41.31: He causes the deep to boil like water in a pot, and churns the sea like one stirs ointment.
41.32: The sea is luminescent behind him; his wake turns the sea white, like those with gray hair.
41.33: "There's nothing like him on earth; he was created without the ability to fear.
41.34: He looks down on everything that is high; he rules over every kind of pride."

42.2: "I know that you can do anything and nothing that you plan is impossible.
42.3: You asked, 'Who is this that darkens counsel without knowledge?' Well now, I have talked about what I don't understand— awesome things beyond me that I don't know.
42.4: Listen now, and I will speak for myself; I'll interrogate you and then inform me.
42.5: I've heard you with my ears; and now I've seen you with my eyes.
42.6: As a result, I despise myself and repent in dust and ashes."
42.7: After these words had been spoken by the LORD to Job, the LORD spoke to Eliphaz from Teman: "My anger is burning against you along with your two friends, since you haven't spoken correctly about me, as did my servant Job.
42.8: So take seven bulls and seven rams and bring them to my servant Job. And bring a whole burnt offering for yourselves and my servant Job will pray for you. I'll encourage him by not responding as your disgraceful folly deserves, since you didn't speak about me correctly as did my servant Job.
42.9: So Eliphaz from Teman, Bildad from Shuah, and Zophar from Naamath did precisely as the LORD had spoken to them, because the LORD showed favor to Job.
42.10: The LORD restored Job's prosperity after he prayed for his friends. The LORD doubled everything that Job had once possessed.
42.11: Then all his brothers and sisters and all those who knew him before arrived. They ate food with him in his house, mourned for him, and consoled him for all the trouble that the LORD had brought and placed on him. Some gave him gold bullion and some brought gold earrings.
42.12: The LORD blessed Job during the latter part of his life more than the former, since he owned 14,000 sheep, 6,000 camels, 1,000 teams of oxen and 1,000 female donkeys.
42.13: He also had seven sons and three daughters.
42.14: He named the first daughter Jemima, the second Keziah, and the name of the third was Keren-happuch.
42.15: No one could find more beautiful women in the whole land than Job's daughters. Their father gave them their inheritance along with their brothers.
42.16: Job lived 140 years after this, and saw his children and grandchildren to the fourth generation.
42.17: Then Job died at an old age, having lived a full life.

1.1: How blessed is the person, who does not take the advice of the wicked, who does not stand on the path with sinners, and who does not sit in the seat of mockers.
1.2: But he delights in the LORD's instruction, and meditates in his instruction day and night.
1.3: He will be like a tree planted by streams of water, yielding its fruit in its season, and whose leaf does not wither. He will prosper in everything he does.
1.4: But this is not the case with the wicked. They are like chaff that the wind blows away.
1.5: Therefore the wicked will not escape judgment, nor will sinners have a place in the assembly of the righteous.
1.6: For the LORD knows the way of the righteous, but the way of the wicked will be destroyed.

2.1: Why are the nations in an uproar, and their people involved in a vain plot?
2.2: As the kings of the earth take their stand and the rulers conspire together against the LORD and his anointed one, they say,
2.3: "Let us tear off their shackles from us, and cast off their chains."
2.4: He who sits in the heavens laughs; the Lord scoffs at them.
2.5: In his anger he rebukes them, and in his wrath he terrifies them:
2.6: "I have set my king on Zion, my holy mountain."
2.7: Let me announce the decree of the LORD that he told me: "You are my son, today I have become your father.
2.8: Ask of me, and I will give you the nations as your inheritance, the ends of the earth as your possession.
2.9: You will break them with an iron rod, you will shatter them like pottery."
2.10: Therefore, kings, act wisely! Earthly rulers, be warned!
2.11: Serve the LORD with fear, and rejoice with trembling.
2.12: Kiss the son before he becomes angry, and you die where you stand. Indeed, his wrath can flare up quickly. How blessed are those who take refuge in him.

3.1: LORD, I have so many persecutors! Many are rising up against me!
3.2: Many are saying about me, "God will never deliver him!" Interlude
3.3: But you, LORD, are a shield around me, my glory, and the one who lifts up my head.
3.4: I cry aloud to the LORD, and he answers me from his holy mountain. Interlude
3.5: I lie down and sleep, I wake up, because the LORD sustains me.
3.6: I will not fear multitudes of people, who set themselves against me on every side.
3.7: Arise, LORD! Deliver me, my God! For you strike the jaw of all my enemies, and you break the teeth of the wicked.
3.8: Deliverance comes from the LORD! May your blessing be on your people. Interlude

4.1: When I call, answer me, my righteous God! When I was in distress, you set me free. Be gracious to me and hear my prayer.
4.2: You people, how long will you malign my reputation? How long will you love what is vain and what is false? Interlude
4.3: But understand this: the LORD has set apart the godly for himself! The LORD will hear me when I cry out to him!
4.4: Be angry, yet do not sin. Think about this when upon your beds, and be silent. Interlude
4.5: Offer sacrifices that are righteous, and put your confidence in the LORD.
4.6: Many are asking, "Who will help us to see better days?" LORD, may the light of your favor shine upon us.
4.7: You have given me more joy in my heart than at harvest times, when grain and wine abound.
4.8: I will lie down and sleep in peace, for you alone, LORD, enable me to live securely.

5.1: LORD, listen to my words, consider my groaning.
5.2: Pay attention to my cry for help, my king and my God, for unto you will I pray.
5.3: LORD, in the morning you will hear my voice; in the morning I will pray to you, and I will watch for your answer.
5.4: Indeed, you aren't a God who delights in wickedness; evil will never dwell with you.
5.5: Boastful ones will not stand before you; you hate all those who practice wickedness.
5.6: You will destroy those who speak lies. The LORD abhors the person of bloodshed and deceit.
5.7: But I, because of the abundance of your gracious love, may come into your house. In awe of you, I will worship in your holy Temple.
5.8: LORD, lead me in your righteousness because of my enemies. Make your path straight before me.
5.9: But as for the wicked, they do not speak truth at all. Inside them there is only wickedness. Their throat is an open grave, on their tongue is deceitful flattery.
5.10: Declare them guilty, God! Let them fall by their own schemes. Drive them away because of their many transgressions, for they have rebelled against you.
5.11: Let all those who take refuge in you rejoice! Let them shout for joy forever, and may you protect them. Let those who love your name exult in you.
5.12: Indeed, you will bless the righteous one, LORD, like a large shield, you will surround him with favor.

6.1: LORD, in your anger, do not rebuke me, in your wrath, do not discipline me.
6.2: Be gracious to me, LORD, because I am fading away. Heal me, because my body is distressed.
6.3: And my soul is deeply distressed. But you, LORD, how long do I wait?
6.4: Return, LORD, save my life! Deliver me, because of your gracious love.
6.5: In death, there is no memory of you. Who will give you thanks where the dead are?
6.6: I am weary from my groaning. Every night my couch is drenched with tears, my bed is soaked through.
6.7: My eyesight has faded because of grief, it has dimmed because of all my enemies.
6.8: Get away from me, all of you who practice evil, for the LORD has heard the sound of my weeping.
6.9: The LORD has heard my plea; the LORD receives my prayer.
6.10: As for all my enemies, they will be put to shame; they will be greatly frightened and suddenly turn away ashamed.

7.1: LORD, my God, I seek refuge in you. Deliver me from those who persecute me! Rescue me!
7.2: Otherwise, they will rip me to shreds like a lion, tearing me apart with no one to rescue me.
7.3: LORD, my God, if I have done this thing, if there is injustice on my hands,
7.4: if I have rewarded those who did me good with evil, if I have plundered my enemy without justification,
7.5: then, let my enemy pursue me, let him overtake me, and let him trample my life to the ground. Interlude Let him put my honor into the dust.
7.6: Get up, LORD, in your anger! Rise up, because of the fury of my enemies; Arouse yourself for me; you have ordained justice.
7.7: Let the assembly of the peoples gather around you, and you will sit high above them.
7.8: For the LORD will judge the peoples. Judge me according to my righteousness, LORD, and according to my integrity, Exalted One.
7.9: Let the evil of the wicked come to an end, but establish the righteous. For you are the righteous God who discerns the inner thoughts.
7.10: God is my shield, the one who delivers the upright in heart.
7.11: God is a righteous judge, a God who is angry with sinners every day.
7.12: If the ungodly one doesn't repent, God will sharpen his sword; he will string his bow and prepare it.
7.13: He prepares weapons of death for himself, he makes his arrows into fiery shafts.
7.14: But the wicked one travails with evil, he conceives malice and gives birth to lies.
7.15: He digs a pit, even excavates it; then he fell into the hole that he had made.
7.16: The trouble he planned will return on his own head, and his violence will descend on his skull.
7.17: But as for me, I will praise the LORD for his righteousness, and I will sing to the name of the LORD Most High.

8.1: LORD, our Lord, how excellent is your name in all the earth! You set your glory above the heavens!
8.2: Out of the mouths of infants and nursing babies you have established strength on account of your adversaries, in order to silence the enemy and vengeful foe.
8.3: When I look at the heavens, the work of your fingers, the moon and the stars that you established—
8.4: what is man that you take notice of him, or the son of man that you pay attention to him?
8.5: You made him a little less than divine, but you crowned him with glory and honor.
8.6: You gave him dominion over the work of your hands, you put all things under his feet:
8.7: Sheep and cattle—all of them, wild creatures of the field,
8.8: birds in the sky, fish in the sea— whatever moves through the currents of the oceans.
8.9: LORD, our Lord, how excellent is your name in all the earth!

9.1: I will give thanks to the LORD with all my heart, I will declare all your wonderful deeds.
9.2: I will be glad and exult in you; I will sing praises to your name, Most High!
9.3: When my enemies turn back, they will stumble and perish before you.
9.4: For you have brought about justice for me and my cause; you sit on the throne judging righteously.
9.5: You rebuked the nations, you destroyed the wicked, you wiped out their name forever and ever.
9.6: The enemy has perished, reduced to ruins forever. You uprooted their cities, the very memory of them vanished.
9.7: But the LORD sits on his throne forever; his throne is established for judgment.
9.8: He will judge the world righteously and make just decisions for the people.
9.9: The LORD is a refuge for the oppressed, a refuge in times of distress.
9.10: Those who know your name will trust you, for you have not forsaken those who seek you, LORD.
9.11: Sing praises to the LORD who dwells in Zion; declare his mighty deeds among the peoples.
9.12: As an avenger of blood, he remembers them; he has not forgotten the cry of the afflicted.
9.13: Be gracious to me, LORD, take note of my affliction, because of those who hate me. You snatch me away from the gates of death,
9.14: so I may declare everything for which you should be praised in the gates of the daughter of Zion, so I will rejoice in your deliverance.
9.15: The nations have sunk down into the pit they made, their feet are ensnared in the trap they set.
9.16: The LORD has made himself known, executing judgment. The wicked are ensnared by what their hands have made. Interlude
9.17: The wicked will turn back to where the dead are — all the nations that have forgotten God.
9.18: For he will not always overlook the plight of the poor, nor will the hope of the afflicted perish forever.
9.19: Rise up, LORD, do not let man prevail! The nations will be judged in your presence.
9.20: Make them afraid, LORD, Let the nations know that they are only human. Interlude

10.1: Why do you stand far away, LORD? Why do you hide in times of distress?
10.2: The wicked one arrogantly pursues the afflicted, who are trapped in the schemes he devises.
10.3: For the wicked one boasts about his own desire; he blesses the greedy and despises the LORD.
10.4: With haughty arrogance, the wicked thinks, "God will not seek justice." He always presumes "There is no God."
10.5: Their ways always seem prosperous. Your judgments are on high, far away from them. They scoff at all their enemies.
10.6: They say to themselves, "We will not be moved throughout all time, and we will not experience adversity."
10.7: Their mouth is full of curses, lies, and oppression, their tongues spread trouble and iniquity.
10.8: They wait in ambush in the villages, they kill the innocent in secret.
10.9: Their eyes secretly watch the helpless, lying in wait like a lion in his den. They lie in wait to catch the afflicted. They catch the afflicted when they pull him into their net.
10.10: The victim is crushed, and he sinks down; the helpless fall by their might.
10.11: The wicked say to themselves, "God has forgotten, he has hidden his face, he will never see it."
10.12: Rise up, LORD! Raise your hand, God. Don't forget the afflicted!
10.13: Why do the wicked despise God and say to themselves, "God will not seek justice."?
10.14: But you do see! You take note of trouble and grief in order to take the matter into your own hand. The helpless one commits himself to you; you have been the orphan's helper.
10.15: Break the arm of the wicked and evil man; so that when you seek out his wickedness you will find it no more.
10.16: The LORD is king forever and ever; nations will perish from his land.
10.17: LORD, you heard the desire of the afflicted; you will strengthen them, you will listen carefully,
10.18: to do justice for the orphan and the oppressed, so that men of the earth may cause terror no more.

11.1: I take refuge in the LORD. So how can you say to me, "Flee like a bird to the mountains."?
11.2: Look, the wicked have bent their bow and placed their arrow on the string, to shoot from the darkness at the upright in heart.
11.3: When the foundations are destroyed, what can the righteous do?
11.4: The LORD is in his holy Temple; the LORD's throne is in the heavens. His eyes see, his glance examines humanity.
11.5: The LORD examines the righteous, but the wicked and those who love violence, he hates.
11.6: He rains on the wicked burning coals and sulfur; a scorching wind is their destiny.
11.7: Indeed, the LORD is righteous; he loves righteousness; the upright will see him face-to-face.

12.1: Help, LORD, for godly people no longer exist; trustworthy people have disappeared from humanity.
12.2: Everyone speaks lies to his neighbor; they speak with flattering lips and hidden motives.
12.3: The LORD will cut off all slippery lips, and the tongue that boasts great things,
12.4: those who say, "By our tongues we will prevail; our lips belong to us. Who is master over us?"
12.5: "Because the poor are being oppressed, because the needy are sighing, I will now arise," says the LORD, "I will establish in safety those who yearn for it."
12.6: The words of the LORD are pure, like silver refined in an earthen furnace, purified seven times over.
12.7: You, LORD, will keep them safe, you will guard them from this generation forever.
12.8: The wicked, however, keep walking around, exalting the vileness of human beings.

13.1: How long? LORD, will you forget me forever? How long will you hide your face from me?
13.2: How long must I struggle in my soul at night and have sorrow in my heart during the day? How long will my enemy rise up against me?
13.3: Look at me! Answer me, LORD, my God! Give light to my eyes! Otherwise, I will sleep in death;
13.4: Otherwise, my enemy will say, "I have overcome him;" Otherwise, my persecutor will rejoice when I am shaken.
13.5: As for me, I have trusted in your gracious love, my heart will rejoice in your deliverance.
13.6: I will sing to the LORD, for he has dealt bountifully with me.

14.1: Fools say to themselves, "There is no God." They are corrupt and commit evil deeds; not one of them practices what is good.
14.2: The LORD looks down from the heavens upon humanity to see if anyone shows discernment as he searches for God.
14.3: All have turned away, together they have become corrupt; no one practices what is good, not even one.
14.4: Will those who do evil ever learn? They devour my people like they devour bread, and never call on the LORD.
14.5: There they are seized with terror, because God is with those who are righteous.
14.6: You would frustrate the plans of the oppressed, but the LORD is their refuge.
14.7: May Israel's deliverance come from Zion! When the LORD restores the fortunes of his people, Jacob will rejoice, and Israel will be glad.

15.1: LORD, who may stay in your tent? Who may dwell on your holy mountain?
15.2: The one who lives with integrity, who does righteous deeds, and who speaks truth to himself.
15.3: The one who does not slander with his tongue, who does no evil to his neighbor, and who does not destroy his friend's reputation.
15.4: The one who despises those who are utterly wicked, but who honors the one who fears the LORD, who keeps his word even when it hurts and does not change,
15.5: who does not loan his money with interest, and who does not take a bribe against those who are innocent. The one who does these things will stand firm forever.

16.1: Keep me safe, God, for I take refuge in you.
16.2: I told the LORD, "You are my master, I have nothing good apart from you."
16.3: As for the saints that are in the land, they are noble, and all my delight is in them.
16.4: Those who hurry after another god will have many sorrows; I will not present their drink offerings of blood, nor will my lips speak their names.
16.5: The LORD is my inheritance and my cup; you support my lot.
16.6: The boundary lines have fallen in pleasant places for me; truly, I have a beautiful heritage.
16.7: I will bless the LORD who has counseled me; indeed, my conscience instructs me during the night.
16.8: I have set the LORD before me continuously; because he stands at my right hand, I will stand firm.
16.9: Therefore, my heart is glad, my whole being rejoices, and my body will dwell securely.
16.10: For you will not leave my soul in Sheol, you will not allow your holy one to experience corruption.
16.11: You cause me to know the path of life; in your presence is joyful abundance, at your right hand there are pleasures forever.

17.1: LORD, hear my just plea! Pay attention to my cry! Listen to my prayer, since it does not come from lying lips.
17.2: Justice for me will come from your presence; your eyes see what is right.
17.3: When you probe my heart, and examine me at night; when you refine me, you will find nothing wrong, for I have determined that I will not transgress with my mouth.
17.4: As for the ways of mankind, I have, according to the words of your lips, avoided the ways of the violent.
17.5: Because my steps have held fast to your paths, my footsteps have not faltered.
17.6: I call upon you, for you will answer me, God. Listen closely to me and hear my prayer.
17.7: Show forth your gracious love, save those who take refuge in you from those who rebel against your sovereign power.
17.8: Protect me as the most precious part of the eye; hide me under the shadow of your wings
17.9: from the wicked who have afflicted me, from my enemies who have surrounded me.
17.10: They are imprisoned by their own prosperity, they have boasted proudly with their mouth.
17.11: Now they have encircled our paths and are determined to cast us down to the ground.
17.12: Like a lion they desire to rip us to pieces, like a young lion waiting in ambush.
17.13: Arise, LORD, confront them, bring them to their knees! Deliver me from the wicked by your sword—
17.14: from men, LORD, by your hand— from men who belong to this world, whose reward is only in this life. But as for your treasured ones, may their stomachs be full, may their children have an abundance, and may they leave wealth to their offspring.
17.15: But as for me, justified, I will behold your face; when I awake, your presence will satisfy me.

18.1: He said: "I love you, Lord, my strength.
18.2: The LORD is my rock, my fortress, my deliverer, my God, my stronghold in whom I take refuge, my shield, the glory of my salvation, and my high tower."
18.3: I cried out to the LORD, who is worthy to be praised, and I was delivered from my enemies.
18.4: The cords of death entangled me; the rivers of Belial made me afraid.
18.5: The cords of Sheol surrounded me; the snares of death confronted me.
18.6: In my distress I cried to the LORD; to my God I cried for help. From his Temple he heard my voice; my cry reached his ears.
18.7: The world shook and trembled; the foundations of the mountains quaked, they shook because he was angry.
18.8: In his anger smoke poured out of his nostrils, and consuming fire from his mouth; coals were lit from it.
18.9: He bent the sky and descended, and darkness was under his feet.
18.10: He rode upon a cherub and flew; he soared upon the wings of the wind.
18.11: He made darkness his hiding place, his canopy surrounding him was dark waters and thick clouds.
18.12: The brightness before him scattered the thick clouds, with hail stones and flashes of fire.
18.13: Then the LORD thundered in the heavens, and the Most High sounded aloud, calling for hail stones and flashes of fire.
18.14: He shot his arrows and scattered them; with many lightning bolts he frightened them.
18.15: Then the channels of the sea could be seen, and the foundations of the earth were uncovered because of your rebuke, LORD, because of the blast from the breath of your nostrils.
18.16: He reached down and took me; he drew me from many waters.
18.17: He delivered me from my strong enemies, from those who hated me because they were stronger than I.
18.18: They confronted me in the day of my calamity, but the LORD was my support.
18.19: He brought me out to a spacious place; he delivered me, for in me he takes delight.
18.20: The LORD will reward me because I am righteous; because my hands are clean he will restore me;
18.21: because I have kept the ways of the LORD, and I have not wickedly departed from my God;
18.22: because all his judgments were always before me, and I did not cast off his statutes.
18.23: I was upright before him, and I kept myself from iniquity.
18.24: So the LORD restored me according to my righteousness, because my hands were clean in his sight.
18.25: To the holy, you show your gracious love, to the upright, you show yourself upright;
18.26: to the pure, you show yourself pure, and to the morally corrupt, you appear to be perverse.
18.27: Indeed, you deliver the oppressed, but you bring down those who exalt themselves in their own eyes.
18.28: For you, LORD, make my lamp shine; my God enlightens my darkness.
18.29: With your help I will run through an army, with help from my God I leap over walls.
18.30: As for God, his way is upright; the word of God is pure; he is a shield to all those who take refuge in him.
18.31: For who is God but the LORD, and who is a Rock other than our God?—
18.32: the God who clothes me with strength, and who makes my way upright;
18.33: who makes my feet swift as the deer; who makes me stand on high places;
18.34: who teaches my hands to make war, and my arms to bend a bronze bow.
18.35: You have given to me the shield of your deliverance, and your right hand holds me up; your gentleness made me great.
18.36: You make a broad place for my steps, so my feet won't slip.
